CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  The
  issuer of a homebuilderâ€™s commercial general liability policy sought a
  declaratory judgment to determine whether the policy covered a homeownerâ€™s
  claim for damages caused by the negligence of a construction subcontractor.Â 
  The trial court determined that the homeownerâ€™s claim fell within the policyâ€™s
  coverage and this appeal followed.Â  We certified
  the case pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  We now withdraw our prior
  opinion and substitute it with this opinion.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in
  part.Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
Respondent Trinity Construction, Inc. (â€œTrinityâ€)
  completed the construction of a home for Respondent Virginia Newman
  (â€œHomeownerâ€) in May 1999.Â  Shortly thereafter, the Homeowner filed a claim
  against Trinity for breach of contract, negligence, and breach of warranty,
  alleging defective construction primarily related to the installation of the
  stucco siding.Â  Based on the report of an engineer hired by the Homeowner to
  inspect the homeâ€™s construction, the Homeowner alleged that the application of
  the stucco did not conform to industry standards and that these nonconforming
  aspects of the stucco installation allowed water to seep into the home causing
  severe damage to the homeâ€™s framing and exterior sheathing.Â  The Homeowner and
  Trinity referred the action to binding arbitration in which an arbitrator
  issued the Homeowner an award of itemized damages due to the defective
  construction totaling $55,898.Â  
At the time of construction, Trinity held a commercial
  general liability (CGL) policy issued by Appellant Auto-Owners Insurance
  Company (â€œAuto-Ownersâ€).Â  Following arbitration, Auto-Owners sought a
  declaratory judgment to determine its rights and obligations under the CGL
  policy, contending that the damages awarded by the arbitrator were not covered
  under the policy.Â  The trial court determined that the policy covered the
  damages because they resulted from an â€œoccurrenceâ€ and because Auto-Owners
  failed to show that any policy exclusions applied.Â  Accordingly, the trial
  court determined that the CGL policy covered all but four items of the damages
  provided for in the arbitration award.Â  Auto-Owners appealed.Â  After certifying
  the case, we affirmed the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Auto-Owners Ins. Co., Inc.
    v. Newman, Op. No. 1383 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 10, 2008) (Shearouse
  Adv. Sh. No. 9 at 63).Â  

	On rehearing, we now consider the following issue for
  review:
	Did the trial court err in holding that the damages
  awarded by the arbitrator for negligent construction were covered under a CGL
  policy?Â Â  

Standard of review
A declaratory judgment action is neither legal nor equitable,
  and therefore, the standard of review is determined by the nature
  of the underlying issue.Â  Colleton County Taxpayers Assâ€™n v. Sch.
    Dist. of Colleton County, 371 S.C. 224, 231, 638 S.E.2d 685, 688 (2006).Â  When
  the purpose of the underlying dispute is to determine whether coverage exists
  under an insurance policy, the action is one at law.Â  Auto-Owners Ins. Co.
    v. Haman, 368 S.C. 536, 540, 629 S.E.2d 683, 685 (Ct. App. 2006). Â In an
  action at law tried without a jury, the appellate court will not disturb the
  trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless there is no evidence to reasonably
  support them. Id.Â Â  
Law/Analysis
A.  Negligent construction as
  an â€œoccurrenceâ€ under the policy
Auto-Owners argues that the arbitratorâ€™s award for the
  Homeownerâ€™s property damage is not covered by the policy.Â  Specifically,
  Auto-Owners argues that pursuant to this Courtâ€™s opinion in L-J v. Bituminous
    Fire & Marine Insurance Co., 366 S.C. 117, 621 S.E.2d 33 (2005), the
  subcontractorâ€™s defective installation of stucco did not cause an â€œaccidentâ€
  constituting an â€œoccurrenceâ€ subject to coverage under the policy.Â  We
  disagree. 
The CGL
  policy issued by Auto-Owners in this case is the standard Insurance Services
  Office (ISO) CGL policy used since 1986 and is identical to that reviewed by
  this Court in L-J.Â  The relevant policy provisions state that Auto
  Owners will â€œpay those sums that the insured becomes legally obligated to pay
  as damages because of â€˜bodily injuryâ€™ or â€˜property damageâ€™ to which this
  insurance applies.â€Â  The policy further explains that the insurance applies to
  such â€œbodily injuryâ€ or â€œproperty damageâ€ only if it is caused by an â€œoccurrence.â€Â  
The CGL policy
  defines many of the particular terms used to outline the scope of its
  coverage.Â  The policy defines â€œproperty damageâ€ as â€œphysical injury to tangible
  property, including all resulting loss of use of that property,â€ and defines an
  â€œoccurrenceâ€ as â€œan accident, including continuous or repeated exposure to
  substantially the same harmful conditions.â€Â  The policy does not define the
  term â€œaccident,â€ however, and this Court has found that in the absence of a
  prescribed definition in the policy, the definition of â€œaccidentâ€ is â€œ[a]n
  unexpected happening or event, which occurs by chance and usually suddenly,
  with harmful result, not intended or designed by the person suffering the harm
  or hurt.â€Â  Green v. U. Ins. Co. of America, 254 S.C. 202, 206, 174 S.E.2d
  400, 402 (1970).Â  
We
  begin our analysis in this case with a review of L-J, which all parties,
  as well as the trial court, assert in support of their respective resolutions
  of the issue.Â  In L-J, a developer hired L-J, Inc. (â€œL-Jâ€) as contractor
  for the site development and road construction in a subdivision development.Â 
  366 S.C. at 119, 621 S.E.2d at 34.Â  L-J hired subcontractors to perform most of
  the work, and four years after construction was completed, the roads began to
  deteriorate due to negligent road design, preparation, and construction.Â  Id.Â  The developer sued L-J and the parties settled.Â  L-J subsequently sought
  indemnification from Bituminous Fire and Marine Insurance Company
  (â€œBituminousâ€) and three other insurance companies who insured L-J under
  various CGL policies.Â  Id.Â  Bituminous refused to indemnify L-J and
  brought a declaratory judgment action to determine whether its CGL policy
  issued to L-J covered the damage to the roads caused by the negligent
  construction.Â  Id. at 120, 621 S.E.2d at 34.Â  
This Court
  found that although the deterioration to the roadways may have constituted
  property damage, the various negligent acts of the subcontractors upon which
  the developer based its claim did not constitute an â€œoccurrenceâ€ for which the
  CGL policy provided coverage.Â  Id. at 123, 621 S.E.2d at 36.Â 
  Specifically, the Court found that the developerâ€™s claim alleged negligent
  construction causing damage only to the defective work product itself (i.e. the
  roadway), and that such a claim was merely one for faulty workmanship.Â  Id.Â  Reasoning that â€œfaulty workmanship is not something that is typically
  caused by an accident or by exposure to the same general harmful conditions,â€
  the Court held that the developerâ€™s claim did not allege an â€œoccurrenceâ€
  falling within the policyâ€™s scope of coverage.Â  Id.Â  See also Isle of
    Palms Pest Control Co. v. Monticello Ins. Co., 319 S.C. 12, 16, 459 S.E.2d
  318, 320 (Ct. App. 1994) (explaining that a claim solely for economic losses
  resulting from faulty workmanship is part of an insuredâ€™s contractual liability
  which a CGL policy is not intended to cover).
The L-J court went on to explain, however, that
  a CGL policy may provide coverage where faulty workmanship causes third party
  bodily injury or damage to other property besides the defective work product.Â  Id. n.4.Â  To illustrate this theory, the Court examined the case of High
    Country Associates v. New Hampshire Insurance Co., in which a condominium
  homeownersâ€™ association sued the condominium builder seeking damages allegedly
  due to negligent construction of the condominium buildings.Â  648 A.2d 474, 476
  (N.H. 1994).Â  The complaint alleged that the continuous moisture intrusion
  resulting from a subcontractorâ€™s defective installation of siding resulted in
  moisture seeping into the buildings, which caused widespread decay of the
  interior and exterior walls and loss of structural integrity over a nine-year
  period.Â  Id.Â  The High Country court found that the complaint was
  not simply a claim for faulty workmanship seeking damages to repair the
  defective siding itself, but rather, was a claim for negligent construction
  resulting in damage to other property.Â  Id. at 477.Â  The court
  determined that the continuous exposure to moisture due to the defective
  installation of siding constituted an â€œoccurrenceâ€ under the policy and that,
  in this way, the homeownersâ€™ association had properly â€œalleged negligent
  construction that resulted in an occurrence, rather than an occurrence of
  alleged negligent construction.â€Â  Id. at 478.Â  Accordingly, High
    Country held that the CGL policy would cover the homeownersâ€™ associationâ€™s
  claim against the builder, if successful.Â  Id.
We find High Country equally instructive in
  determining whether a CGL policy provides coverage in the instant case where an
  arbitrator determined that the Homeowner incurred damages as a result of the
  negligent application of stucco by Trinityâ€™s subcontractor.Â  Specifically, the
  arbitrator found that the defective stucco allowed for continuous moisture
  intrusion resulting in substantial water damage to the homeâ€™s exterior
  sheathing and wooden framing.[1]Â 
  In our view, these findings establish that there was â€œproperty damageâ€ beyond
  that of the defective work product itself, and that therefore, the Homeownerâ€™s
  claim is not merely a claim for faulty workmanship typically excluded under a
  CGL policy.
Furthermore, although the subcontractorâ€™s negligent
  application of the stucco does not on its own constitute an â€œoccurrence,â€ we
  find that the continuous moisture intrusion resulting from the subcontractorâ€™s
  negligence is an â€œoccurrenceâ€ as defined by the CGL policy.Â  In our view, the
  continuous moisture intrusion into the home was â€œan unexpected happening or
  eventâ€ not intended by Trinity - in other words, an â€œaccidentâ€ - involving â€œcontinuous or
  repeated exposure to substantially the same harmful conditions.â€Â  See Travelers
    Indem. Co. of Am. v. Moore & Assocs., 16 S.W.3d 302, 309 (Tenn.
  2007) (holding that whether an â€œaccidentâ€ has occurred under the terms of a CGL
  policy requires a court to determine whether damages would have been
  foreseeable if the insured had completed the work properly).Â  Accordingly, we
  hold that the subcontractorâ€™s negligence resulted in an â€œoccurrenceâ€ falling
  within the CGL policyâ€™s initial grant of coverage for the resulting â€œproperty
  damageâ€ to the homeâ€™s framing and exterior sheathing.Â  See also Penn. Mfrs.
    Assoc. Ins. Co. v. Dargan Constr. Co.,2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 53366
  (D.S.C. July 13, 2006).
We note that interpreting â€œoccurrenceâ€ as we do in this
  case gives effect to the subcontractor exception to the â€œyour workâ€ exclusion
  in the standard CGL policy.Â  On this matter, a brief history of CGL policies is
  instructive.Â  A CGL policy in the home construction industry is designed to cover
  the risks faced by homebuilders when a homeowner asserts a post-construction
  claim against the builder for damage to the home caused by alleged construction
  defects.Â  See Rowland H. Long, The Law of Liability Insurance, Â§
  3.06(1) (2007).Â  Several construction-specific exclusions in the standard CGL
  policy exclude from coverage certain types of property damage attributable to
  risks outside the scope of CGL recovery.Â  See id.Â  The primary
  exclusion is the â€œyour workâ€ exclusion which provides that the policy will not
  cover â€œâ€˜property damageâ€™ to â€˜your work.â€™â€Â  In 1986, the insurance industry
  amended the â€œyour workâ€ exclusion to provide that even if the property damage
  is to the builderâ€™s own work, the â€œyour workâ€ exclusion does not apply â€œif the
  damaged work or the work out of which the damage arises was performed on your
  behalf by a subcontractor.â€Â  See French v. Assurance Co. of America, 448
  F.3d 693, 701 (4th Cir. 2006) (discussing the evolution of the standard CGL
  policy).Â  In doing so, the insurance industry extended liability coverage for
  property damage to the contractorâ€™s completed work arising out of work
  performed by the subcontractor.[2]Â  Id.Â  
The facts of this case establish exactly the type of
  property damage the CGL policy was intended to cover after the 1986 amendment
  to the â€œyour workâ€ exclusion.Â  In construing the provisions of an insurance
  policy, the Court must consider the policy as a whole and adopt a construction
  that gives effect to the whole instrument and to each of its various parts and
  provisions.Â  Yarborough v. Phoenix Mut. Life Ins. Co., 266 S.C. 584,
  592, 225 S.E.2d 344, 349 (1976).Â  To interpret â€œoccurrenceâ€ as narrowly as
  Auto-Owners suggests would mean that any time a subcontractorâ€™s negligence led
  to the damage of any part of the contractorâ€™s overall project, a CGL insurer
  could deny recovery on the basis that it is excluded from the policyâ€™s initial
  grant of coverage.Â  This interpretation would render both the â€œyour workâ€
  exclusion and the subcontractorâ€™s exception to the â€œyour workâ€ exclusion in the
  policy meaningless. [3]Â Â Â  See French, 448 F.3d at 705-06. 
For these reasons, we hold that the trial court
  correctly found that the negligent application of stucco resulted in an
  â€œoccurrenceâ€ of water intrusion, causing â€œproperty damageâ€ that is covered
  under Trinityâ€™s CGL policy.
B.  Operation of policy
  exclusion to exclude damages awarded for replacing the substrate
Auto-Owners argues that even if the subcontractorâ€™s
  negligent application of stucco resulted in an â€œoccurrenceâ€ under the CGL
  policy, coverage for the resulting property damage is nevertheless barred by a
  policy exclusion.Â  We disagree.
An exclusion found in the standard CGL policy
  prohibits coverage for â€œâ€˜property damageâ€™ expected or intended from the
  standpoint of the insured.â€[4]Â 
  Auto-Owners claims that pursuant to this exclusion, damages awarded by the
  arbitrator related to the framing and exterior sheathing of the home are not
  covered under the CGL policy because a construction professional would expect
  substantial moisture intrusion from defective stucco to result in these types
  of damages.Â  In our opinion, and in the absence of any evidence otherwise, it
  is unreasonable to believe that Trinity expected or intended its subcontractor
  to perform negligently.Â  Therefore, Trinity could not have expected or intended
  the resulting property damage.Â  Cf. Lamar Homes v. Mid-Continent Cas. Co.,
  242 S.W.3d 1, 8 (Tex. 2007) (â€œBut a deliberate act, performed negligently, is
  an accident if the effect is not the intended or expected result; that is, the
  result would have been different had the deliberate act been performed
  correctly.â€).Â  Accordingly, we hold that
  the property damage to the homeâ€™s framing and exterior sheathing was not
  expected or intended by Trinity, and therefore, coverage of the Homeownerâ€™s
  property damage is not barred by this exclusion contained in the CGL policy.Â Â Â  
C.  Damages awarded for
  replacement of the defective stucco
Auto-Owners finally argues that even if an
  â€œoccurrenceâ€ warrants recovery for the Homeownerâ€™s property damage, the trial
  court erred in determining that the CGL policy covered the arbitratorâ€™s
  itemized allowance for replacing and repairing the defective stucco itself as
  an incidental cost to repairing the damage to other property.Â  We agree.Â  
The
  standard CGL policy grants the insured broad liability coverage for property
  damage and bodily injury which is then narrowed by a number of exclusions.Â 
  Each exclusion in the policy must be read and applied independently of every
  other exclusion.Â  Engineered Products, Inc. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co.,
  295 S.C. 375, 378-79, 368 S.E.2d 674, 675-76 (Ct. App. 1988) (quoting Weedo
    v. Stone-E-Brick, Inc., 405 A.2d 788, 795 (N.J. 1979)).Â  
Although
  the subcontractor exception preserves coverage for property damage that would
  otherwise be excluded as â€œyour work,â€ another policy exclusion bars coverage
  for damage to the defective workmanship itself.Â  Specifically, the policy
  exclusion provides that the insurance does not cover damages â€œclaimed for any
  loss, cost or expense . . . for the repair, replacement, adjustment, removal or
  disposal of . . . â€˜Your productâ€™; . . . â€˜Your workâ€™; or . . . â€˜Impaired
  propertyâ€™; if such product, work or property is withdrawn . . . from use . . .
  because of a known or suspected defect, deficiency, inadequacy or dangerous
  condition in it.â€Â  These terms unambiguously prohibit recovery for the cost of
  removing and replacing the defective stucco - even when the replacement of the
  defective work may be incidental to the repair of property damage covered by
  the policy - and serve as one of the bases for this Courtâ€™s acknowledgment that
  a claim solely for economic losses resulting from faulty workmanship is part of
  an insuredâ€™s contractual liability which a CGL policy is not intended to cover.Â  See L-J, 366 S.C. at 122, 621 S.E.2d at 35.Â  Accordingly, we hold
  that any amount in the arbitratorâ€™s allowance allotted to the removal and
  replacement of the defective stucco is not covered under the CGL policy. 
Nevertheless, it is not possible from the record
  before this Court to determine what portion of the arbitratorâ€™s itemized list
  of damages may be attributed to the removal and replacement of the defective
  stucco, and it is not the purpose of this declaratory judgment action to
  relitigate the issue of damages.Â  Auto-Owners had an opportunity to raise this
  matter when the issue of damages was litigated before the arbitrator, who
  issued a final, binding award on the merits.[5] Â See Pittman Mortg. Co. v. Edwards, 327 S.C. 72, 76, 488 S.E.2d 335, 337
  (1997) (â€œGenerally, an arbitration award is conclusive and courts will refuse
  to review the merits of an award.â€).Â  

Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s
  decision finding that the CGL policy issued by Auto-Owners to Trinity covers
  the damage awarded by the arbitrator to the Homeowner.Â  Although we reverse the
  trial courtâ€™s decision to the extent that it orders recovery under the policy
  for the removal and replacement of the defective stucco, there is no evidence
  in the record indicating which damages
  may be attributed to the removal and replacement of the defective stucco. Â 
WALLER,
  BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate
  opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  We have held that faulty
  workmanship by a subcontractor which results in property damage only to the
  work product itself is not an occurrence within the meaning of that term in a
  comprehensive general liability (CGL) policy.Â  L-J, Inc. v. Bituminous Fire
    and Marine Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 117, 621 S.E.2d 33 (2005).Â  Here, the general
  contractorâ€™s â€œwork productâ€ is the entire home, including the stucco, the
  framing, and the exterior sheathing.Â  In my view, there is no coverage under
  the CGL policy because there is no occurrence, rather only faulty workmanship.Â  L-J, Inc., supra.
As
  we explained in Century Indemnity Co. v. Golden Hills Bldrs., Inc., 348
  S.C. 559, 561 S.E.2d 355 (2002):

	A
  comprehensive general liability policy, such as the one at issue, provides
  coverage â€œfor all the risks of legal liability encountered by a business
  entity,â€ with coverage excluded for certain specific risks.Â  Rowland H. Long,
  L.L.M., The Law of Liability Insurance, Â§ 3.06[1] (2001).Â  This type of
  insurance â€œis not intended to insure business risks, i.e., risks that
  are normal, frequent, or predictable consequences of doing business, and which
  business management can and should control or manage.â€Â  Id. Â§ 10.01
  [1].Â  Specifically, â€œ[t]he policies do not insure [an insuredâ€™s] work itself,
  but rather, they generally insure consequential risks that stem from that
  work.â€Â  Id. See also Isle of Palms Pest Control Co. v. Monticello
    Ins. Co., 319 S.C. 12, 459 S.E.2d 318 (Ct.App. 1995), affâ€™d, 321
  S.C. 310, 468 S.E.2d 304 (1996) (general liability policy is intended to
  provide coverage for tort liability for physical damage to property of others;
  it is not intended to provide coverage for insuredâ€™s contractual liability
  which causes economic losses); Sapp v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 226 Ga.App. 200, 486 S.E.2d 71, 75 (1997) (noting risk intended to be insured is
  possibility that work of insured, once completed, will cause bodily injury or
	damage
    to property other than to completed work itself, and for which insured may
  be found liable; coverage applicable under CGL policy is for tort liability for
  injury to persons and damage to other property and not for contractual
  liability of insured for economic loss because completed work is not that for
  which the damaged person bargained).

Id. at 565-66, 561 S.E.2d at 358 (emphasis in original).
Under the relevant
  provisions of this CGL policy, Auto Owners is responsible for â€œproperty damageâ€
  that is caused by an â€œoccurrence.â€Â  â€œOccurrenceâ€ as used in the policy â€œmeans
  an accident, including continuous or repeated exposure to substantially the
  same general harmful conditions.â€Â  Faulty workmanship by subcontractors which
  leads to deterioration or damages the work product itself is not an accident
  within the meaning of a CGL policy.Â  L-J, Inc., supra.[6]Â 
  In L-J, as the majority notes, we also explained that there may be
  coverage where faulty workmanship causes third party bodily injury or damage to
  property other than the contractorâ€™s work product.Â  Here, we have neither
  bodily injury nor damage to anything other than the contractorâ€™s work product.Â  
The
  majority relies on High Country Assocs. v. New Hamp. Ins. Co., 139 N.H.
  39, 648 A.2d 474 (1994), and finds that damage caused to other parts of the
  house by the stucco subcontractorâ€™s faulty workmanship is a claim of property
  damage beyond that of the defective work itself, and thus covered under the
  policy.Â  I disagree.
As noted above, the
  â€œwork productâ€[7] is the entire home constructed by Trinity for the Homeowners.Â  See L-J,
    Inc., supra.Â  While I agree that High Country appears to
  distinguish between the construction of the condominium units themselves (the
  work product) and the damage done to the structure of these units, a later New
  Hampshire case which cites High Country makes it clear that coverage
  under a CGL policy exists only where there is actual damage to property other
  than the insuredâ€™s work product.Â  Webster v. Acadia Ins. Co., 156 N.H.
  317, 934 A.2d 567 (2007) (CGL coverage where negligent installation of new roof
  caused damage to preexisting rafters).Â  As I understand High Country in
  light of Webster, there would be no coverage here as only Trinityâ€™s
  â€œwork productâ€ has been damaged as a result of the stucco subcontractorâ€™s
  faulty workmanship.
Finally,
  I do not believe we need look at the terms of a policyâ€™s exclusion in order to
  determine coverage.Â  Under existing South Carolina law, there is no occurrence
  here, thus no property damage, and therefore no coverage.Â  The â€œyour workâ€
  exclusion applies only where there is, in fact, â€œproperty damageâ€ to â€œyour
  work.â€Â  Absent that threshold showing of coverage, there is no reason to reach
  the exclusion, much less the subcontractor exception to the exclusion.Â  Compare Laidlaw Enviro. Serv. (TOC) v. Aetna Cas. & Assur. Co. of Ill., 338
  S.C. 43, 524 S.E.2d 847 (Ct. App. 1999) (exclusion does not create coverage but
  limits it).
I would reverse.


[1] According to expert testimony from the consulting engineer hired by the Homeowner,
  the subcontractorâ€™s application of stucco did not meet applicable building code
  requirements and deviated from industry standards.Â  The expert testified that
  the subcontractor did not apply the stucco to the required thickness; failed to
  install a weep system or flashing around doors and windows; and used improper
  caulking and banding methods.
[2] C.D. Walters Construction Co., Inc. v. Firemanâ€™s Insurance Co., cited by
  Auto-Owners in support of its argument, is distinguishable from the instant
  case because it denied coverage under a CGL policy based on the â€œyour workâ€
  policy exclusion before the 1986 modification to cover damage resulting from
  subcontractor negligence.Â  281 S.C. 593, 597-98, 316 S.E.2d 709, 712 (Ct. App. 1984). 
We would
  also distinguish this Courtâ€™s decision in Century Indemnity Co. v. Golden
    Hills Builders, Inc., 348 S.C. 559, 561 S.E.2d 355 (2002), because the
  coverage period for the policy at issue expired while the contractor was still
  in possession of the home.Â  
[3] In adopting this interpretation, the dissent asserts that we need not â€œlook at
  the terms of a policyâ€™s exclusion in order to determine coverage.â€Â 
  Nevertheless, in order to determine the proper meaning of the term
  â€œoccurrence,â€ we must read the policy as a whole and consider â€œthe context and
  subject matter of the insurance contract.â€Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire and
    Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â  We decline to
  adopt any construction of the CGL policy that renders a significant exclusion
  meaningless, notwithstanding the objections voiced by the dissent.Â Â  
[4] We note that instead of containing an exclusion to this effect, the pre-1986
  CGL policy included this language in its initial grant of coverage as part of
  the definition of â€œoccurrence.â€Â  See French, 448 F.3d at 701.Â  Although,
  in our view, an analysis under our modern jurisprudence as to whether or not
  there was an â€œoccurrenceâ€ essentially subsumes this particular 1986 amendment
  to the policy, we set forth an analysis of the exclusionâ€™s applicability in
  this case for the sake of completeness.
[5] Auto-Owners represented Trinity in binding arbitration, made mandatory by the
  terms of the insurance contract.Â  Auto-Owners did so with a reservation of
  rights and an understanding that the coverage issue would be reserved for
  judicial consideration in a separate proceeding.Â  When the arbitrator determined
  damages, Auto-Owners did not seek review of or otherwise contest the damages
  award.Â  
[6] In my opinion, the definition of â€œaccidentâ€ in Travelers Indem. Co. of Am.
  v. Moore & Assoc., 216 S.W.3d 302 (Tenn. 2007), relied upon by the
  majority, is fundamentally inconsistent with the definition we adopted in L-J,
    Inc., supra.Â  See Gen. Sec. Indem. Co. of Az. v. Mtn.
      States Mut. Cas. Co., 205 P.3d 529 (Colo. App. 2009) (identifying L-J,
        Inc. as following majority rule that construction defect claims are not
  accidents under a CGL policy and Moore as a minority rule decision).Â Â Â  
[7] The CGL does not use this term: it is a combination of â€œyour productâ€ and â€œyour
  work,â€ both terms defined under the contract.Â  Here, we are actually talking
  about â€œyour workâ€ which means:Â Â Â Â Â  

	a.  work or
  operations performed by you or on your behalf; and
	b.  materials,
  parts or equipment furnished in connection with such work or operations.

description: The Court reverses the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of the remedy of rescission in a breach of contract action.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Cecil Brazell
      and Jackie Brazell, Petitioners,
				v.
				Audrey B.
      Windsor, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Charleston County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26715
Heard June 10, 2009 - Filed September 8,
  2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Brian
  Dumas, of Peake, Fowler & Associates, of Columbia, for Petitioners.
				J.
  Rutledge Young, Jr., Stephen L. Brown, William L. Howard, Sr., and Russell G.
  Hines, all of Young, Clement, Rivers, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Petitioners
  filed a breach of contract action against Respondent arising out of a purchase
  contract for the sale of a home and sought rescission of the entire contract.Â 
  The trial court granted Respondentâ€™s 12(b)(6), SCRCP, motion to dismiss the
  remedy of rescission and the court of appeals affirmed.Â  We granted a writ of
  certiorari to review that decision and now reverse.Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
On October 20, 2004, Petitioners and Respondent
  entered into a sales contract for the purchase of a home located on Edisto
  Island.Â  The closing took place on November 30, 2004.Â  Although neither party
  was present at the closing, Petitioners executed a HUD-1 Settlement Statement
  and a deed to Respondent prior to the closing, and the parties submitted
  pre-signed closing documents at the closing.Â  The total purchase price of the
  home was $550,000, and after satisfying liens on the property, Petitioners were
  to receive $327,818.54.
On December 3, 2004, Respondent notified Petitioners
  that the reverse osmosis water filtration system did not work.Â  On December 6,
  2004, the deed was recorded.Â  Respondentâ€™s attorney forwarded a check of the
  net proceeds to Petitioners but withheld $2,000 from the check and noted that
  the amount reflected the â€œsellersâ€™ proceeds less $2,000 escrow for reverse
  osmosis system repair.â€Â  The attorney sent an escrow agreement regarding how
  the parties would treat the $2,000.Â  Petitioners refused to sign the escrow
  agreement and refused to accept the check.Â  
Petitioners filed suit alleging breach of contract and
  seeking rescission of the entire contract.Â  The trial court reviewed the complaint
  as well as the HUD-1 Statement and granted Respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss the
  remedy of rescission.Â 
  The court of appeals affirmed.Â  Brazell v. Windsor, 376 S.C. 83, 655
  S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the
  following issues:

	
		
			I. 
			Did the court of appeals err in holding that the 
			Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, motion was not converted into a motion for summary
  judgment after the trial court considered the HUD-1 Statement, which was not
  attached to the complaint?
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the court of appeals err in holding the trial 
			court properly granted the motion to dismiss the remedy of 
			rescission?
		
	

Standard of
  Review
Under Rule 12(b)(6), a defendant may move
  to dismiss a complaint based on a failure to state facts sufficient to constitute
  a cause of action.Â  If the facts and inferences drawn from the facts alleged in
  the complaint, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, would
  entitle the plaintiff to relief on any theory, then the grant of a motion to
  dismiss for failure to state a claim is improper.Â  Gentry v. Yonce, 337
  S.C. 1, 5, 522 S.E.2d 137, 139 (1999). Â In deciding whether the trial court
  properly granted the motion to dismiss, the appellate court must consider
  whether the complaint, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff,
  states any valid claim for relief. Â Id.
Law/Analysis
I. HUD-1 Statement
Petitioners argue that the court of appeals erred in
  holding that the trial court did not convert the 12(b)(6) motion into a summary
  judgment motion in considering the HUD-1 Statement which was not attached to
  the complaint.Â  We disagree.
In the complaint, Petitioners alleged that Respondent
  had not paid the amount due under the sales contract â€œas set forth upon the
  HUD-1 Settlement Statement attached to and incorporated herein by reference.â€Â 
  Although Petitioners failed to actually attach the HUD-1 Statement to the
  complaint, Respondentâ€™s counsel attached a copy of it to their memorandum in
  support of
  the motion to dismiss the remedy of rescission.Â  The trial court specifically referenced
  the HUD-1 statement in its order and considered the document in making the
  ruling.
A copy of a document which is an exhibit to a pleading
  is a part of the pleading for all purposes if a copy is attached to such a
  pleading. Â Rule 10(c), SCRCP.Â Â Â  In considering a
  12(b)(6) motion, the trial court must base its ruling solely upon the allegations
  set forth on the face of the complaint.Â  However, on a 12(b)(6) motion,
  if matters outside the pleading are presented to and not excluded by a court,
  the motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed of as
  provided in Rule 56, SCRCP, and all parties shall be given reasonable
  opportunity to present all material made pertinent to such a motion by Rule 56.Â  See Rule 12(b), SCRCP.
We hold that the trial court did not convert the
  12(b)(6) motion into a motion for summary judgment by considering the HUD-1
  Statement in making his ruling.Â  Petitioners explicitly stated that the
  Statement was attached and incorporated by reference into the complaint.Â  Thus,
  they brought the HUD-1 Statement to the attention of trial court and were on
  notice of any information contained in it. Â In our view, allowing a trial court
  to consider documents that are incorporated by reference in the complaint but
  not actually attached thereto prevents a plaintiff from benefiting from his own
  oversight or from surviving a motion to dismiss by intentionally omitting
  documents upon which their claims are based.Â  
Accordingly, we hold that the trial court did not
  convert the 12(b)(6) motion into a motion for summary judgment by considering
  the HUD-1 Statement.Â  
II. Motion to Dismiss
Petitioners argue the court of appeals erred in
  affirming the trial courtâ€™s grant of Respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss the remedy
  of rescission.Â  We agree.
A breach of contract claim warranting
  rescission of the contract must be so substantial and fundamental as to defeat
  the purpose of the contract.Â  Rogers v.
    Salisbury Brick Corp., 299
  S.C. 141, 143, 382 S.E.2d 915, 917 (1989).
  Â Thus, a rescission will not be granted for a minor or
  casual breach of a contract, but only for those breaches which defeat the
  object of the contracting parties.Â  Id. at 143-44, 382 S.E.2d at 917.Â 
  In the absence of fraud, rescission is appropriate only if both parties can be
  returned to the status quo prior to the contract.Â  King v. Oxford, 282
  S.C. 307, 313, 318 S.E.2d 125, 129 (Ct. App.
  1984).Â  

	In the complaint, Petitioners alleged
  Respondent breached the contract:
	
		
			
				a.
				In proceeding with the closing on
  terms other than those as specified in the written agreement; 
 
			
			
				b.
				In failing to honor the â€œtime is
  of the essenceâ€ provision of the agreement;
 
			
			
				c. 
				In failing initially to forward
  any proceeds of the sale as specified in the duly executed HUD-1 Settlement
  Statement to the [Petitioners] in a timely manner;
 
			
			
				d. 
				
				In failing to subsequently forward
  appropriate funds as clearly specified on the HUD-1 Settlement Statement;
			
			
				e.
				By arbitrarily and unilaterally
  withholding funds from the [Petitioners]; all of the above constituting substantial
  and material breaches of the written agreement for sale of real estate as
  existing between the parties.
			
		
	


The trial court found that the allegation
  that Respondent withheld $2,000 from the contract price was a minor breach as a
  matter of law and that rescission would not restore either party to the status
  quo.Â  Similarly, the court of appeals held that the remedy of rescission was
  not available because the alleged breach was not fundamental or substantial
  enough to defeat the purpose of the contract.Â  However, the court of appeals
  declined to address whether the parties could be returned to the status quo in
  light of its dispositive holding that the breach was not fundamental.
We hold that the trial court erred in
  granting Respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss the remedy of rescission, and likewise,
  that the court of appeals erred in affirming this decision.Â  In the complaint, Petitioners alleged Respondent breached several
  provisions in the contract by withholding $2,000 from the purchase price.Â 
  While $2,000 may constitute a relatively small portion of the total purchase
  price, Petitioners alleged the withholding of the proceeds was a material
  breach, and thus, the allegations support a claim for relief.
In our view, the trial courtâ€™s and court
  of appealsâ€™ error stems from focusing on the dollar amount withheld in determining whether Respondentâ€™s actions defeated
  the purpose of the contract and the objective of the contracting parties.[1]Â 
  Numerous legal documents are executed in a real estate transaction and several
  entities involved in the transaction, including the buyer, seller, lender,
  mortgage company, and title insurance company, rely on the finality of the
  closing.Â  Indeed, this Court has noted the importance of attorneysâ€™ compliance
  with the proper real estate closing standards in disciplinary matters.Â  See
    In re Barbare, 360 S.C. 560, 573, 602 S.E.2d 382, 388 (2004) and In re Lathan, 360 S.C. 326, 339, 600 S.E.2d 902, 908-09 (2004) (noting the Courtâ€™s trouble with â€œreal estate
  transactions which have been the subject of misleading, fraudulent, and/or
  criminal schemes. Inaccurate HUD-1 Settlement Statements and other closing
  documents contribute to these deceptive activities.â€).Â  For these reasons, real
  estate contracts are unique and courts should evaluate the purpose of
  the real estate contract and the materiality of a breach in light of these
  differences.
In the instant case, we find that the overriding
  purpose of the contract was not merely to receive proceeds from the sale of a
  home, but rather to finalize a real estate transaction and transfer title from
  Petitioners to Respondent.Â  Respondent could have negotiated for provisions in
  the contract regarding the reverse osmosis system or could have sought relief
  by filing her own breach of contract action.Â  By withholding proceeds from the
  purchase price, however, the transaction was not final, thereby potentially
  defeating the purpose of the contract.
As a final matter, we hold that the trial court erred
  in dismissing the remedy of rescission because the parties could not be
  restored to the status quo.Â  Petitioners immediately took action after
  Respondent failed to act in accordance with the contract.Â  When Respondent
  failed to deliver the entire amount specified in the contract, Petitioners
  instructed Respondent not to file the deed or take any further action regarding
  title to the property.Â  Petitioners refused to accept the check or sign the
  escrow agreement.Â  Nine days later, Petitioners filed the breach of contract
  action seeking rescission of the contract â€œreturning the parties to the status
  quo.â€Â  Moreover, it is feasible and practicable to transfer title in the
  property back to Petitioners and return any additional moneys paid to restore
  the parties to their original position.Â  See Ellie,
    Inc. v. Miccichi, 358
  S.C. 78, 94, 594 S.E.2d 485, 494 (Ct. App.
  2004) (noting that rescission entitles the party to a return of the
  consideration paid as well as any additional sums necessary to restore him to
  the position occupied prior to the making of the contract).Â  
We note that whether it would be fair and equitable to
  rescind the contract is a different issue from whether Petitioners have
  sufficiently alleged a material breach of contract and sufficiently alleged
  that rescission would allow them to be restored to the status quo.Â Â  See King, 282 S.C. at 314-15, 318 S.E.2d at 129 (refusing to rescind the
  contract where the plaintiff would be materially prejudiced by rescission and
  where the defendant could not restore the plaintiff to his former position).Â 
  Likewise, whether Petitioners would be able to survive a motion for summary
  judgment is a different issue from whether Petitioners have failed to state a
  claim.Â  We merely hold that because Petitioners have stated facts which, if
  true, would entitle them to relief, the trial court erred in granting
  Respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss the remedy of rescission.Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the court of
  appeals correctly held that the trial court did not convert the 12(b)(6) motion
  into a motion for summary judgment in considering the HUD-1 Settlement
  Statement, but erred in affirming the grant of Respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss
  the remedy of rescission.Â  Accordingly, we reverse and remand for further
  proceedings.Â  
WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E.
  Moore, concur. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent and would affirm the Court of
  Appeals which upheld the trial courtâ€™s order granting respondentâ€™s Rule 12
  (b)(6), SCRCP motion.Â  In my opinion, placing $2,000 in an escrow account
  pending resolution of the reverse osmosis system issue may not have been the
  best decision, but it was in no way â€œso substantial and fundamental as to
  defeat the purpose of the contract.â€Â  Moreover, I do not agree with the
  majority that a special standard should apply to real estate transactions,
  since in my view the purpose of any sale is to transfer title from the seller
  to the buyer.Â  Finally, I agree with the trial judge that rescission cannot lie
  here as it is impossible to return respondent to the status quo ante the
  closing.
I would affirm.Â Â  


[1] In the order, the trial court noted that Respondent paid 99.6% of the contract
  price and withheld only .04%.Â  The court found that Petitionersâ€™ complaint was
  â€œover a minor .04%.â€

description: In this case, the Court held that an inmate injured while serving time on weekends may not combine his prison pay with full time wages in determining his average weekly wage, for purposes of workers' compensation.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				James A. Smith, Respondent,
				v.
				Barnwell County, Employer, and South Carolina
      Association of Counties Self Insurance Fund, Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal from Barnwell County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26716
Heard June 10, 2009 - Filed September 8,
  2009Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Richard
  Kale, Jr., of Wilson, Jones, Carter & Baxley, of Greenville, for Appellants.
				Andrew
  Nathan Safran, of Columbia, for Respondent.
				Grady
  L. Beard and Daniel W. Hayes, both of Sowell, Gray, Stepp & Laffitte, of Columbia,
  for Amicus Curiae. 
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  This case presents the
  question whether an inmate injured while serving time on weekends may include
  his full time employment wages in addition to prison pay in determining his
  average weekly wage, for purposes of workersâ€™ compensation.Â  Because we find
  that the legislature intended to deny inmates the right to combine wages, we
  find that Respondent may not do so.Â  We therefore reverse the circuit courtâ€™s
  decision to the contrary.
FACTS
After
  a conviction for driving under the influence, Appellant James A. Smith served
  time on weekends at the Barnwell County Detention Center, where he was directed
  to engage in various work activities.[1]Â 
  Smith also worked during the week at Bowe Construction.Â  While working at a
  landfill during his weekend sentence, Smith fell from a tractor and injured his
  back.
Barnwell County elected
  to cover its prisoners under the workersâ€™ compensation program, as allowed by
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-500 (2005).Â  Barnwell County accepted Smithâ€™s claim for
  workersâ€™ compensation and began paying him compensation based upon an average
  weekly wage of $40 a week, the amount provided in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-7-65 (2005)
  as the average weekly wage for county and municipal prisoners.Â  Smith then
  filed a Form 50 with the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission contending that the
  average weekly wage from his regular employment, which he claimed was $333.82,
  should also be included in determining his compensation.
Following
  a hearing, the single commissioner ruled that Smith could not include the
  average weekly wage from his regular employment.Â  The full commission affirmed
  and the circuit court reversed the full commission.Â  Barnwell County appealed.

ISSUES

	
		
			I. 
			Did the circuit court err in finding that Smith is an â€œemployeeâ€ 
			of Barnwell County?
 
		
		
			II.
			Did the circuit court err in finding that Smith may combine 
			wages from civilian employment with the statutory average weekly 
			wage for county prisoners?
		
	

DISCUSSION
The
  amount of compensation awarded under the workersâ€™ compensation statutes is
  based on the workerâ€™s average weekly wage.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-40 provides
  the method for calculating the average weekly wage, but allows for deviation
  from the method â€œfor exceptional reasons . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-40
  (2005).Â  This Court has held that concurrent employment is one such exceptional
  reason.Â  See Foreman v. Jackson Minit Markets, Inc., 265 S.C.
  164, 217 S.E.2d 214 (1975).
Barnwell County argues on appeal that Smith was not an
  â€œemployeeâ€ of Barnwell County and therefore, since Smith was not working for
  two or more employers when the injury occurred, Smith may not recover
  compensation for concurrent employment.Â  We need not reach this issue because
  we agree with the County that, even assuming Smith is an â€œemployeeâ€ for workersâ€™
  compensation purposes, he may not combine wages under Â§ 42-1-40.Â  
Originally,
  the average weekly wage for prisoners was addressed in Â§ 42-1-40, which
  contained the â€œexceptional reasonsâ€ provision.[2]Â 
  In 1983, after this Courtâ€™s decision in Foreman, the General Assembly
  removed the inmate section from Â§ 42-1-40 and included it in the newly-created
  Â§ 42-7-65, which contains no â€œexceptional reasonsâ€ provision.Â  Section 42-7-65
  is entitled â€œAverage weekly wage designated for certain categories of
  employeesâ€[3] and provides in part, â€œ[t]he average weekly wage for county and municipal
  prisoners is forty dollars a week.â€
By
  removing inmates from Â§ 42-1-40, designating a specific weekly wage for
  inmates, and not providing an â€œexceptional reasonsâ€ provision in Â§ 42-7-65, we
  find that the General Assembly intended that inmates not be allowed to combine
  wages in determining their average weekly wage.Â  Compare Boles v. Una
    Water District, 291 S.C. 282, 353 S.E.2d 286 (1987) (holding that volunteer
  firefighter may combine wages where firefighterâ€™s average weekly wage was set
  forth in Â§ 42-1-40).Â  If the General Assembly had not intended such a result,
  there would have been no reason to remove inmates from Â§ 42-1-40.Â  See Cannon
    v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Serv., 371 S.C. 581,
  430, 641 S.E.2d 429, 584 (2007), citing Denene, Inc. v. City of
    Charleston, 352 S.C. 208, 574 S.E.2d 196 (2002) (it must be presumed the
  Legislature did not intend a futile act, but rather intended its statutes to
  accomplish something).
Given
  the above, we find that the General Assembly intended to deny inmates the
  ability to combine wages in determining their average weekly wage.Â  See State
    v. Scott, 351 S.C. 584, 588, 571 S.E.2d 700, 702 (2002) (The cardinal rule
  of statutory interpretation is to ascertain the intent of the legislature.). Â Smith
  is therefore limited to the average weekly wage provided by Â§ 42-7-65.[4]
CONCLUSION
Assuming arguendo that Smith is an â€œemployeeâ€ for purposes of the workersâ€™
  compensation statute, we find that Smith may not combine wages.Â  The General
  Assembly did not intend for an inmate to be able to combine wages in
  determining his average weekly wage.
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Though the record is silent as to whether Smithâ€™s labor was mandatory or
  voluntary, he was apparently engaged in a voluntary program for labor on public
  works allowed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-235 (2005).
[2] Though Â§ 42-1-40 only specifically addressed the average weekly wage of inmates
  of the State of South Carolina, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-500 (1977) provided for
  workerâ€™s compensation coverage for certain county inmates in accordance with
  the statutes addressing coverage for State inmates.Â  
[3] 1983 Act No. 33, Â§ 1; county prisoners were added in 1991 Act. No. 16, Â§ 2.
[4] We reject Smithâ€™s argument that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-7-65 (2005), as interpreted
  by Appellant, is penal in nature and so, must be strictly construed against the
  governmental entity seeking to enforce it.Â  â€œA determination of whether a
  statute is civil or criminal in nature is primarily a question of statutory
  construction, which begins by reference to the actâ€™s text and legislative
  history.â€Â  See In re Matthews, 345 S.C. 638, 648, 550 S.E.2d 311,
  316 (2001).Â  â€œWhere the legislature has manifested its intent that the
  legislation is civil in nature, the party challenging that classification must
  provide â€˜the clearest proof that the statutory scheme is so punitive in either
  purpose or effect as to negate the [legislatureâ€™s] intention.â€™â€ Id.Â  In the instant case, Smith has failed to show the punitive nature of Â§ 42-7-65,
  a part of the workerâ€™s compensation act.

				Esten B

  District Court for the District of South Carolina presents certified questions
  concerning commercial general liability (CGL) insurance policies.Â  We are
  asked, as an issue of first impression in South Carolina, whether the
  respective policiesâ€™ inclusion of an advertising injury may encompass trademark
  infringement.Â  Generally, based on the policy terms before us, we answer in the
  affirmative. Â We are not asked nor do we attempt to offer an opinion on the ultimate
  issues of coverage in this case.Â  The ultimate questions of coverage remain
  with the federal district court.
I.
Super Duper, Inc., a
  South Carolina corporation, manufactures education and therapy materials for
  children.Â  Mattel, Inc., an international toy manufacturer, challenged Super
  Duperâ€™s registration of four trademarks and filed formal notices of opposition
  and petitions for cancellation with the United States Patent and Trademark
  Office.Â  Super Duper brought a declaratory judgment action in the federal
  district court to determine if its trademark infringed on Mattelâ€™s trademarks. Â Mattel
  counterclaimed asserting trademark infringement along with other claims.
Super Duper was
  insured by Travelers Indemnity Company of America and Travelers Property
  Casualty Company of America (collectively â€œTravelersâ€) and Pennsylvania
  National Mutual Casualty Insurance Company (â€œPenn Nationalâ€) under commercial
  general liability insurance policies for â€œadvertising injury.â€ Â Super Duper
  notified Travelers and Penn National about the trademark infringement
  counterclaims and requested coverage.Â  Travelers and Penn National denied
  coverage and refused to provide Super Duper a defense.Â  Thus, Super Duper
  defended itself.Â  Subsequently, Mattel prevailed on its trademark infringement
  claims.
Super
  Duper brought this action in the federal district court seeking a declaratory
  judgment and damages for failure to defend or indemnify, breach of contract,
  and bad faith.
A.
This
  case involves three CGL policies provided by Travelers: 1999 policy (effective
  from August 26, 1999 through August 26, 2000), 2000 policy (effective from
  August 26, 2000 through August 26, 2001), and 2005 policy (effective from
  August 26, 2005 through August 26, 2006).Â  The 1999 and 2000 CGL policies
  include the following definition:

	â€œAdvertising injuryâ€ means
  injury arising out of one or more of the following offenses:
	a.  Oral or written publication of material that slanders
  or libels a person or organization or disparages a personâ€™s or organizationâ€™s
  goods, products or services;
	b.  Oral or written publication of material that violates
  a personâ€™s right of privacy;
	c.  Misappropriation of advertising ideas or style of
  doing business; or
	d.  Infringement of copyright, title or slogan.

(emphasis added).[1]Â 
  The 2005 policy redefined â€œadvertising injuryâ€ as arising out of one or more of
  the following offenses:

	a.  Oral, written or electronic
  publication of material that slanders or libels a person or organization or
  disparages a personâ€™s or organizationâ€™s goods, products or services, provided
  that claim is made or â€œsuitâ€ is brought by a person or organization that claims
  to have been slandered or libeled, or whose goods, products or services have
  allegedly been disparaged;
	b.  Oral, written or electronic
  publication of material that appropriates a personâ€™s likeness, unreasonably
  places a person in a false light or gives unreasonable publicity to a personâ€™s
  private life; or
	c.  Infringement of copyright,
  title or slogan, provided that claim
  is made or â€œsuitâ€ is brought by a person or organization claiming ownership of such
  copyright, title or slogan.

(emphasis
  added).[2]
 Effective from
  August 26, 2005 to August 26, 2006, Travelers provided a Commercial Excess Liability
  Umbrella (CUP) insurance policy for Super Duper.Â  This policy also included
  â€œ[i]nfringement of copyright, title or sloganâ€ in its definition of
  â€œadvertising injury.â€
We
  turn next to the Penn National CGL policies, which were in effect August 26,
  2001 through August 26, 2002 (referred to as â€œ2001 policyâ€) and August 26, 2002
  through August 26, 2003 (referred to as â€œ2002 policyâ€).Â  The 2002 policy was
  renewed for consecutive one-year terms, ending on August 26, 2006.Â  Unlike the
  Traveler policies, the relevant Penn National Policies (2001 policy and 2002
  policy) defined â€œadvertisement.â€Â  The 2001 Penn National policy stated,
  â€œâ€˜[a]dvertisementâ€™ means a notice that is broadcast or published to the general
  public or specific market segments about your goods, products or services for
  the purpose of attracting customers or supporters.â€[3]Â 
  The 2002 Penn National policy mirrored the precedent policy only adding
  references about the Internet and websites.
The
  2001 and 2002 Penn National policies also included definitions for â€œpersonal
  and advertising injuryâ€:

	â€œPersonal
  and advertising injuryâ€ means injury, including consequential â€œbodily injury,â€
  arising out of one or more of the following offenses:
	. . . 
	f.Â  The use of anotherâ€™s advertising idea in your
  â€œadvertisementâ€; or
	g.Â  Infringing upon anotherâ€™s copyright, trade dress
  or slogan in your â€œadvertisementâ€.[4]

The 2002 Penn
  National CGL policy also included the following exclusion:

	â€œPersonal
  and advertising injuryâ€ arising out of the infringement of copyright, patent,
  trademark, trade secret or other intellectual property rights.
	However,
  this exclusion does not apply to infringement, in your â€œadvertisement,â€ of
  copyright, trade dress or slogan.

B.
Quoting
  portions of the above Penn National and Travelers policies, the federal court
  certified the following questions in the indemnification action, which this
  Court accepted:

	
		
			1.
			Whether an underlying suit premised upon trademark 
			infringement by the insured qualifies as injury arising out of the 
			offense of â€œmisappropriation of advertising ideas or style of doing 
			business?â€
 
		
		
			2. 
			Whether an underlying suit premised upon alleged 
			trademark infringement by the insured qualifies as injury arising 
			out of the offense of â€œinfringement of copyright, title or slogan?â€
 
		
		
			3.
			Whether an underlying suit premised upon trademark 
			infringement by the insured qualifies as injury arising out of the 
			offense of â€œuse of anotherâ€™s advertising idea in your 
			â€˜advertisement?â€™â€ 
		
		
			4. 
			Whether an underlying suit premised upon trademark 
			infringement by the insured qualifies as injury arising out of the 
			offense of â€œinfringing [upon] anotherâ€™s copyright, trade dress or 
			slogan in your â€˜advertisement?â€™â€[5]
		
	

II.
Although the
  federal district court quoted language from the Travelers and Penn National
  policies in the certified questions posed to this Court, the federal court did
  not seek our determination on the ultimate coverage questions, and we offer no
  such opinion today.Â  Moreover, we neither reach the insurersâ€™ challenge to the
  pleadings in the federal district court, nor do we reach the express exclusion
  in Penn Nationalâ€™s 2002 policy.
We
  now turn to the first two certified questions as they implicate Super Duperâ€™s policies
  with Travelers.
A.

	Question
  1:Â  Whether an underlying suit premised upon trademark infringement by the
  insured qualifies as injury arising out of the offense of â€œmisappropriation of
  advertising ideas or style of doing business?â€

In State Auto Property & Casualty Insurance Co.
  v. Travelers Indemnity Co. of America, 343 F.3d 249, 255-58 (4th Cir.
  2003), the federal court of appeals interpreted the same contract language
  applying North Carolina law.Â  We find the State Auto opinion
  well-reasoned and sound, drawing on basic contract interpretation law to which South Carolina also adheres.[6]Â 
  Today, we adopt its analysis regarding whether trademark infringement constitutes
  an advertising injury.
State Auto began by recognizing the phrase â€œmisappropriation of advertising ideas or style
  of doing businessâ€ presents two distinct questions: â€œ(1) whether
  â€˜misappropriationâ€™ under the Travelers Policy is limited to common law
  misappropriation, or whether it encompasses any claim related to the wrongful
  use of a trademark; and (2) whether a trademark can constitute an advertising
  idea or a style of doing business.â€Â  State Auto, 343 F.3d at 255.
The court in State Auto rejected Travelersâ€™
  contention the undefined term misappropriation refers to the common law tort of
  misappropriation[7] for a multitude of reasons: (1) North Carolinaâ€™s refusal to limit a similar
  phrase, â€œunfair competition,â€ to its common law meaning when interpreting the
  phrase in an insurance policy; (2) the majority of courts interpreting
  â€œmisappropriationâ€ apply a general meaning, not the common law meaning; and (3)
  an ambiguity must be resolved in the policyholderâ€™s favor.Â  343 F.3d at 255-57.
We too reject Travelersâ€™ contention the undefined term
  misappropriation refers to the common law tort of misappropriation as the
  insurance policy makes no such limitation and instead uses the general term
  misappropriation, to which we apply its common meaning.Â  See Schulmeyer
    v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134
  (2003) (â€œWhen a contract is unambiguous a court must construe its provisions
  according to the terms the parties used; understood in their plain, ordinary,
  and popular sense.â€).Â  Generally, misappropriate is â€œto appropriate dishonestly
  for oneâ€™s own use . . . [or] to appropriate wrongly or misapply in use.â€Â  Websterâ€™s Third New International Dictionary 1442 (2002).Â  Trademark infringement is squarely within this definition.
Even
  if we were to find uncertainty with the common understanding of the term
  misappropriation, we would be left with an ambiguity and thus the same result. Â Ambiguous
  terms must be construed in favor of the insured.Â  Greenville County v. Ins. Reserve Fund, 313 S.C. 546, 547-48, 443
  S.E.2d 552, 553 (1994).Â  If Travelers intended to restrict its exposure solely
  to the common law tort of misappropriation, then Travelers had both the means
  and the responsibility to use restrictive language in the contract instead of
  the general term â€œmisappropriation.â€
Next, we turn to part two of question one: whether a
  trademark can qualify as an advertising idea or a style of doing business.Â  State
    Auto began its analysis by listing four functions a trademark serves:

	(1) it identifies and
  distinguishes a sellerâ€™s goods; (2) it indicates that all goods bearing the
  mark derive from the same source; (3) it signifies that all goods bearing the
  mark are of the same quality; and (4) it serves as a prime instrument in the
  advertisement and sale of the sellerâ€™s goods.

State
  Auto, 343 F.3d at 257-58 (citing 1 J. Thomas McCarthy, McCarthy on Trademarks and
  Unfair Competition Â§3:2 (4th ed. 2003)).Â  As a trademark is the prime
  advertising instrument, we adopt State Autoâ€™s holding, â€œat the very least,
  a trademark has the potential to be an advertising idea.â€Â  State Auto,
  343 F.3d at 258.Â  As we do not reach the ultimate coverage issue, we end our
  analysis here with our recognition a trademark has the potential to constitute
  an advertising idea or a style of doing business.
Therefore, we join the majority of courts finding
  misappropriation may include trademark infringement.Â  See Cat Internet Servs., Inc. v.
    Providence Washington Ins. Co., 333 F.3d 138, 142 (3rd Cir. 2003) (â€œWe
  now hold that when a complaint alleges that an insured misappropriates and uses
  trademarks or ideas in connection with marketing and sales and for the purpose
  of gaining customers, the conduct constitutes â€˜misappropriation of an
  advertising idea or style of doing businessâ€™ under Pennsylvania law.â€), Frog, Switch & Mfg. Co., Inc. v.
    Travelers Ins. Co., 193 F.3d 742, 749 (3rd Cir. 1999) (â€œA trademark depends
  for its effectiveness on communicating a message to consumers about the marked
  good, which is the essence of advertising, and therefore allegations of
  trademark infringement arguably allege misappropriation of an advertising
  idea.â€), Adolfo House Distrib. Corp. v. Travelers Prop. & Cas.
    Ins. Co., 165 F.Supp.2d 1332, 1339 (S.D. Fla. 2001) (â€œThis court therefore concludes that allegations of trademark or trade
  dress infringement meet the CGL â€˜advertising injuryâ€™ definition of â€˜advertising
  injuryâ€™ under the definition sub-part for â€˜misappropriation of advertising
  ideas or style of doing business.â€™â€). Â But see Advance Watch Co., Ltd. v. Kemper Nat.
    Ins. Co.,
    99 F.3d 795, 802 (6th Cir. 1996) (â€œ[T]his court concludes,
  contrary to the district courtâ€™s conclusion, that â€˜misappropriation of
  advertising ideas or style of doing businessâ€™ does not refer to a
  category or grouping of actionable conduct which includes trademark or trade
  dress infringement.â€).
In sum, we hold
  misappropriation may encompass a claim related to the wrongful use of a
  trademark, and a trademark may constitute an advertising idea or a style of
  doing business.Â  Accordingly, to the first certified question, we answer yes.
B.

	Question
  2:Â  Whether an underlying suit premised upon alleged trademark infringement by
  the insured qualifies as injury arising out of the offense of â€œinfringement of
  copyright, title or slogan?â€

The 1999 and 2000 Travelers policies defined an
  advertising injury as â€œ[i]nfringement of copyright, title or slogan.â€Â  The 2005
  Travelers policy redefined â€œadvertising injuryâ€ as â€œ[i]nfringement of
  copyright, title or slogan, provided that claim is made or â€˜suitâ€™ is brought by
  a person or organization claiming ownership of such copyright, title or slogan.â€
Again, the policy
  failed to define these terms, and we therefore must look to their common
  meanings.Â  Super Duper conceded at oral argument it made no allegations pertaining
  to copyright; thus, we shall examine the terms title and slogan.Â  A title is â€œa descriptive name.â€Â  Websterâ€™s Third New International Dictionary 2400 (2002).Â  A slogan is â€œa brief striking phrase used in advertising
  or promotion.â€Â  Websterâ€™s Third New International Dictionary 2145 (2002).Â  Therefore, trademarks, titles,
  and slogans are heavily related and can be synonymous.Â  Thus, coverage for
  â€œinfringement of copyright, title or sloganâ€ may envelop trademark
  infringement.Â  See Union Ins.
    Co. v. Knife Co., Inc., 897 F. Supp. 1213,
  1217 (W.D. Ark. 1995) (holding trademark infringement can be described
  as infringement of a title or slogan as â€œboth titles and slogans . . . can
  undoubtedly be protected as trademarksâ€).Â  Accordingly, we answer the second
  certified question yes.
III.
Now, we reach Penn
  Nationalâ€™s policies, as certified questions three and four solely implicate
  this insurer.Â  The quoted language in certified questions three and four appears
  in Penn Nationalâ€™s 2001 and 2002 CGL policies, which state:

	â€œPersonal
  and advertising injuryâ€ means injury, including consequential â€œbodily injuryâ€,
  arising out of one or more of the following offenses:
	. . .
	f.      The use of anotherâ€™s advertising
  idea in your â€œadvertisementâ€; or
	g.     Infringing upon anotherâ€™s
  copyright, trade dress or slogan in your â€œadvertisementâ€.

The Penn National policies
  defined â€œadvertisementâ€ as, â€œa notice that is broadcast or published to the
  general public or specific market segments about your goods, products or
  services for the purpose of attracting customers or supporters.â€Â  The Travelers
  policies include no such definition of â€œadvertisement.â€
A.

	Question
  3:Â  Whether an underlying suit premised upon trademark infringement by the
  insured qualifies as injury arising out of the offense of â€œuse of anotherâ€™s
  advertising idea in your â€˜advertisement?â€™â€

The
  third certified question asks whether trademark infringement may occur when
  anotherâ€™s advertising idea is used.Â  â€œAn â€˜advertising
  ideaâ€™ is an â€˜idea for calling public attention to a product or business,
  especially by proclaiming desirable qualities so as to increase sales or
  patronage.â€™â€Â  Ohio Cas. Ins. Co. v. Cloud Nine, LLC, 464 F.Supp.2d
    1161, 1166 (D. Utah 2006) (quoting Atlantic Mut. Ins. Co. v. Badger Med.
      Supply Co., 528 N.W.2d 486, 490 (Wis. Ct. App. 1995)).Â  As discussed supra,
  there is a close link between advertising and trademarks.Â  This connection
  exists under Penn Nationalâ€™s definition of an advertisement as â€œnotice
  that is broadcast or published to the general public or specific market
  segments about your goods, products or services for the purpose of attracting
  customers or supporters.â€Â  A trademark is â€œany â€˜word, name, symbol, or deviceâ€™
  used by a manufacturer or merchant â€˜to identify his goods and distinguish them
  from those manufactured by others.â€™â€Â  1 J. Thomas
  McCarthy, McCarthy on Trademarks and Unfair Competition Â§3:4 (4th ed.
  2009) (quoting Lanham Act Â§45, 15 U.S.C.A. Â§1127 (Supp. 2009)).
Thus, the use of anotherâ€™s advertising idea may include trademark
  infringement because to infringe upon someoneâ€™s
  trademark, which is an advertising device, one improperly uses anotherâ€™s
  advertising idea to draw the consumerâ€™s attention to a product.Â  Accordingly,
  we answer the third certified question, yes.

B.

	Question
  4:Â  Whether an underlying suit premised upon trademark infringement by the
  insured qualifies as injury arising out of the offense of â€œinfringing [upon]
  anotherâ€™s copyright, trade dress or slogan in your â€˜advertisement?â€™â€

In
  the fourth certified question, this Court must determine whether trademark
  infringement occurs when a party improperly uses anotherâ€™s copyright, trade
  dress or slogan in their advertisement.Â  Again, the definition of copyright is
  not pertinent to this case, so we turn to trade dress and slogan.Â  As discussed supra, a slogan is
  â€œa brief striking phrase used in advertising or promotion.â€Â  Websterâ€™s Third New International Dictionary 2145 (2002).Â  Accordingly,
  we hold a trademark may be a productâ€™s slogan.Â  Therefore, trademark
  infringement potentially relates to the improper use of anotherâ€™s slogan.
Trade dress is a more amorphous concept.Â 
  Historically trade dress included a productâ€™s labels and containers; now trade
  dress refers to the productâ€™s packaging, the productâ€™s shape and design, and
  the totality of elements creating the productâ€™s overall image.Â  1 J. Thomas McCarthy, McCarthy on Trademarks
  and Unfair Competition Â§8.4 (4th ed.
  2009).Â  Further, McCarthy stated, â€œthe history of American law throughout much
  of the Twentieth Century is the gradual disappearance of distinctions between
  the law of â€˜trade dressâ€™ and that of â€˜trademarks.â€™â€Â  1 J. Thomas McCarthy, McCarthy on Trademarks
  and Unfair Competition Â§8.1 (4th ed. 2009).Â  Therefore, a trademark may
  serve as an element to the overall trade dress of a product.
Accordingly,
  we answer the fourth certified question yes, as trademark infringement may
  occur when a party infringes upon anotherâ€™s trade dress or slogan in its advertisement.

IV.
In answering these
  certified questions, we make no judgments regarding the overall coverage issues
  in this case.Â  We answer the certified questions narrowly and conclude, based
  on the policies presented, trademark infringement has the potential to
  constitute an advertising injury.Â  This potential is all we find today.Â  We
  recognize this case requires more analysis, procedurally and substantively, to resolve
  the partiesâ€™ disputes.
CERTIFIED
  QUESTIONS ANSWERED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1]  This
  policy definition is the verbatim language provided by the Insurance Services
  Office (ISO) for commercial general liability (CGL) policies in 1986.Â  6 J. Thomas McCarthy, McCarthy on Trademarks &
  Unfair Competition Â§33:5 (4th ed. 2009).
[2]  Travelers
  apparently did not insure Super Duper in the interim between the 2000 and 2005
  policies.Â  Travelers used a CGL policy during this non-coverage time which
  included an exclusion stating:

	â€œPersonal and advertising injuryâ€
  arising out of the infringement of copyright, patent, trademark, trade secret
  or other intellectual property rights.
	However this exclusion does not
  apply to infringement, in your â€œadvertisementâ€, of copyright, trade dress or
  slogan.

As Travelers conceded at oral argument, this exclusion
  has no application in the case at hand as the 2005 CGL policy deleted this
  exclusion in its entirety.
[3]  The
  â€œadvertisementâ€ definition follows the 1998 standard language by ISO for CGL
  policies.Â  6 J. Thomas McCarthy,
  McCarthy on Trademarks and Unfair Competition Â§33:5 (4th ed. 2009).Â  
[4]  Other
  items in the definition differed slightly among the two policies, but
  subsections f and g are identical.Â  These subsections are also identical to language
  provided by the ISO for CGL policies in 1998.Â 
  6 J. Thomas McCarthy, McCarthy on Trademarks and Unfair Competition Â§33:5 (4th ed. 2009).
[5]  We
  note the second certified question uses the term â€œalleged trademark
  infringement.â€Â  The remaining three questions make no such qualification.
[6]  Compare Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Rollison, 378 S.C. 600, 606, 663 S.E.2d 484, 487
  (2008) (â€œAn insurance policy is a contract between the insured and the
  insurance company, and the terms of the policy are to be construed according to
  contract law.â€), and Superior Auto. Ins. Co. v. Maners,
  261 S.C. 257, 263, 199 S.E.2d 719, 722 (1973) (â€œ[T]o ascertain the intention of
  an instrument resort is first to be had to its language, and if such is
  perfectly plain and capable of legal construction, such language determines the
  force and effect of the instrument.â€), and Forner v. Butler, 319 S.C. 275, 277,
    460 S.E.2d 425, 427 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œWhere the words of
  an insurance policy are capable of two reasonable interpretations, that
  construction will be adopted which is most favorable to the insured.Â 
  Furthermore, exclusions in an insurance policy are to be construed most strongly
  against the insurer.â€) (citation omitted), with State Auto, 343 F.3d at
  254 (â€œAn insurance policy is a contract, and its
  provisions govern the rights and duties of the parties thereto. . . .Â  Further,
  provisions in a policy â€˜which extend coverage to the insured must be construed
  liberally so as to afford coverage whenever possible by reasonable
  construction.â€™â€) (citations omitted).
[7]  The
  common law tort of misappropriation is defined as, â€œ[a] judge-made common law
  form of unfair competition where the defendant has copied or appropriated some
  item or creation of the plaintiff which is not protected by either patent law,
  copyright law, trademark law, or any other traditional theory of exclusive rights.â€Â  J. Thomas McCarthy, McCarthyâ€™s Desk
  Encyclopedia of Intellectual Property 273 (2d ed. 1995). Â Trademark
  infringement would fall outside the common law tort of misappropriation
  definition; however, Travelersâ€™ reliance on the common law tort is improperly
  restrictive.

CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â   In this case, a
  policyholder brought causes of action for breach of contract and bad faith
  rescission against his insurance company, and sought actual and punitive
  damages for the companyâ€™s termination of his health care insurance from

Factual Background
On May 15, 2001, Respondent Jerome Mitchell, Jr.
  (â€œMitchellâ€), of Florence, submitted an application for health insurance to
  Appellant Fortis Insurance Company (â€œFortisâ€).Â  Mitchell, who was seventeen
  years old at the time, was preparing to attend college and was no longer
  covered under his motherâ€™s health insurance policy.Â  The application required
  him to answer a medical questionnaire, which included the question: â€œBeen
  diagnosed as having or been treated for any immune deficiency disorder by a
  member of the medical profession?â€Â  Mitchell answered â€œnoâ€ to this question.Â  Fortis
  issued Mitchell a health insurance policy.
In April 2002,
  Mitchell attempted to donate blood to the Red Cross.Â  On May 13, 2002, the Red
  Cross contacted Mitchell to inform him that his blood had screened positive for
  HIV.Â  The Red Cross suggested Mitchell get a confirmation test from his
  personal physician, and Mitchell immediately contacted Dr. Michael Chandler.Â 
  On May 14, 2002, Dr. Chandlerâ€™s tests confirmed that Mitchell was HIV
  positive.Â  That day, one of Dr. Chandlerâ€™s assistants noted on Mitchellâ€™s

Dr.
  Chandler referred Mitchell to Dr. Kevin Shea, an infectious disease specialist
  with Carolina Health Care (â€œCarolinaâ€).Â  On May 23, 2002, Dr. Shea met with
  Mitchell and recorded Mitchellâ€™s medical history as follows:

	Mr.
  Mitchell is an 18 year old African-American male with no past medical history
  who apparently tried to donate blood in April of this year.Â  He was noted to be
  HIV positive.Â  Subsequent confirmation through Dr. Chandlerâ€™s office included a
  positive ELISA and Western Blot.Â  He is referred at this time for further
  evaluation.Â  Â Â Â Â Â  

Fortis soon
  received claims for Mitchellâ€™s treatment and for the blood testing that
  indicated Mitchell was HIV positive.Â  Pursuant to company policy in cases
  involving long-term disease, Fortis launched an investigation to determine
  whether Mitchell had failed to disclose a pre-existing condition on his policy
  application.
In June 2002, a
  Fortis investigator contacted Mitchell to request that he identify his
