  punitive damages against an insurer who stopped collecting the premiums from
  the insured, with knowledge from the claims filed and from the agentâ€™s observation
  that the insured was near death, so that the policy would lapse); Yarborough
    v. Bankers Life & Casualty Co., 225 S.C. 236, 81 S.E.2d 359 (1954)
  (where the jury awarded $7.50 in actual damages and $1,000 in punitive damages
  against an insurer who repudiated a health insurance policy by failing to send
  a notice of premiums due after the insured filed a claim for gall-bladder
  trouble, and attempted to have the insured agree to a retroactive rider
  excluding illnesses resulting from gall-bladder trouble); Riley v. Life
    & Casualty Ins. Co., 184 S.C. 383, 192 S.E. 394 (1937) (where the jury
  awarded $36 in actual damages and $1,000 in punitive damages against an insurer
  who stopped collecting premiums from the insured after it was clear that his
  health was failing and with the obvious intention to cancel the life insurance
  policy);[9] Jamison v. American Workmen Ins. Co., 169 SC 400, 169 S.E. 83 (1933)
  (where the jury awarded $20 in actual damages and $480 in punitive damages
  against an insurer who stopped notifying the insured when premiums were due
  after the insured became very ill in hopes that the insured would miss a
  payment and thereby justify rescission).Â Â Â  
In reviewing more recent punitive damages awards, South Carolina courts have most often upheld verdicts on the low end of the single-digit
  spectrum, but have frequently deviated from this norm in cases involving
  particularly egregious conduct.[10]Â  See James, 371 S.C. at 196-97, 638 S.E.2d at 671-72 (upholding a 6.82 to
  1 ratio); Mackela v. Bentley, 365 S.C. 44, 614 S.E.2d 648 (Ct. App.
  2005) (upholding a 3.75 to 1 ratio); Austin v. Specialty Transp. Services,
    Inc., 358 S.C. 298, 594 S.E.2d 867 (Ct. App. 2004) (upholding a 2.54 to 1
  ratio); Collins Entertainment Corp. v. Coats & Coats Rental Amusement,
  355 S.C. 125, 584 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 2003) (upholding a 9.96 to 1 ratio); Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali Ins.
    Co., 321 S.C. 1, 466 S.E.2d 727 (1996) (upholding a 28 to
  1 ratio).Â  Cf. Atkinson, 361 S.C. at 170, 604 S.E.2d at 392-93
  (overruling a 127 to 1 ratio).Â  
In
  our view, the conduct in this case was reprehensible enough to merit an award
  towards the outer limits of the single-digit ratio.Â  See Campbell, 538 U.S. at 425 (observing that few awards exceeding a single-digit ratio between punitive and
  compensatory damages will satisfy due process). Â Fortis willfully disregarded
  Mitchellâ€™s health and safety, and the jury so found in assessing this punitive
  damages award.Â  In assessing this remittitur, we place great emphasis upon that
  consideration.Â  
We
  therefore remit the punitive damages award to $10 million, resulting in a ratio
  of 9.2 to 1.Â  We believe a $10 million award in this case satisfies due process
  and comports with South Carolina law.Â  We are also certain that a $10 million
  award will adequately vindicate the twin purposes of punishment and deterrence that
  support the imposition of punitive damages.Â Â  
II.  Evidence
  at Trial
Fortis argues that
  the judgment should be vacated, or judgment rendered in its favor, because the
  circuit court erred in admitting certain evidence.Â  We disagree.Â  
A.Â  Other Rescissions
Fortis
  argues that the circuit court allowed the jury to consider evidence that the
  rescission committee harmed nonparties to the suit, in violation of its
  constitutional rights.Â  See Campbell, 538 U.S. at 420.Â  Fortis asserts that the jury should not have considered evidence indicating
  that forty-five other rescission cases were considered with Mitchellâ€™s in the
  course of a two-hour committee meeting.Â  This argument is without merit.Â  It is
  evident from the record that Mitchell introduced this evidence in order to
  establish the inference that Fortis could not have spent more than three
  minutes in deliberating the rescission of Mitchellâ€™s policy.Â  Fortis could have
  defended itself from such evidence had the rescission committee kept minutes in
  its meetings.Â  The circuit court did not err in allowing this evidence.Â  
B.Â  Post-claim Underwriting
Fortis
  argues that the circuit court erred in allowing testimony regarding Fortisâ€™s
  retrospective investigation practices, also known as â€œpost-claim
  underwriting.â€Â  Fortis asserts that expert testimony indicating that this
  practice is unlawful in â€œat least half a dozen statesâ€ constituted evidence of
  out-of-state conduct that violated Fortisâ€™s constitutional right to due
  process.Â  See Campbell, 538 U.S. 408.Â  We disagree.Â  
Fortis
  argues that, as a general matter, post-claim underwriting is â€œperfectly lawfulâ€
  in South Carolina.Â  However, in the context of this case, Fortisâ€™s post-claim
  underwriting practices played a pivotal role in the harm inflicted upon
  Mitchell in South Carolina.Â  This evidence was probative of Fortisâ€™s bad faith
  conduct, and was properly submitted to the jury. 
C.Â  Improper Litigation Conduct
Fortis
  argues that the trial court erred in allowing the jury to consider evidence
  that Fortis engaged in â€œimproper conductâ€ following the September 4, 2002
  rescission committee meeting on the grounds that â€œdissimilar acts, independent
  from the acts upon which liability was premised, may not serve as the basis for
  punitive damages.â€Â  Campbell, 538 U.S. at 422.Â  We disagree for three
  reasons.Â  
First,
  the rescission was not final until June 2003 review of Mitchellâ€™s â€œappeal.â€ Â At
  a bare minimum, all evidence of concealment until that point is allowable.Â 
  Second, this evidence is probative of Fortisâ€™s bad faith liability, not
  punitive damages.Â  Lastly, Fortis waived any objection to the admission of
  evidence of bad acts that occurred after the second rescission committee
  meeting by: (1) repeatedly emphasizing their own â€œgood actâ€ of reinstatement
  following the â€œtemporaryâ€ rescission, and (2) repeatedly arguing that Mitchell
  himself acted negligently in failing to submit additional information prior to
  March 8, 2004. 
D.Â  Value of
  Mitchellâ€™s Free Medical Treatment
Fortis
  argues that the circuit court erred in allowing the jury to consider the value
  of the free medical care Mitchell received from Hope Health.Â  We disagree.
The
  value of Mitchellâ€™s free medical care is relevant to the determination of
  damages because the collateral source rule provides that an award for damages
  should not be decreased if the plaintiff receives compensation for all or part
  of the damage from a collateral source.Â  See Haselden v. Davis, 353 S.C.
  481, 579 S.E.2d 293 (2003) (holding that the proper measure of damages is the
  â€œreasonable valueâ€ of the medical services, even if the plaintiff receives the
  treatment free or at a discount).Â  In this case, the value of Mitchellâ€™s free
  medical treatment is necessary to the determination of the amount of damage
  Fortis inflicted upon Mitchell in rescinding his policy. 
E.Â  Mitchellâ€™s Future Medical Expenses 
Fortis
  argues that the circuit court erred in allowing the jury to consider the value
  of the Mitchellâ€™s future medical expenses.Â  This objection, however, is
  meritless.Â  This evidence is probative of Fortisâ€™s financial motive to rescind
  Mitchellâ€™s policy, and we find it is relevant to Mitchellâ€™s allegations of bad
  faith.Â  
F.  Mitchellâ€™s Risk of Death 
Without Appropriate Medication
Fortis
  argues that the circuit court erred in allowing the jury to consider the risk
  of death Mitchell faced without treatment, because it was â€œirrelevant, highly
  prejudicial, and . . . inflamed the jury.â€Â  We find this assertion to be
  entirely without merit.Â  Evidence of the risk Mitchell faced without health
  insurance coverage is properly admissible to establish Fortisâ€™s
  reprehensibility and support an award for punitive damages.Â  
III.  Fortisâ€™s
  Motion for JNOV
We
  find it patently clear from the record that there is no support for Fortisâ€™s
  claim that â€œthe evidence as a whole is susceptible to only one reasonable
  inferenceâ€ that Fortis was not liable for bad faith rescission of Mitchellâ€™s
  health insurance policy.Â  
IV.  Passion,
  Caprice, and Prejudice
Similarly,
  we find no credible evidence anywhere in the record to support Fortisâ€™s
  contention that â€œthe juryâ€™s $15 million punitive damages award and/or its
  $150,000 compensatory damages award were the result of passion, caprice, or
  prejudice, and therefore must be reversed and a new trial ordered.â€Â  
Conclusion
For the forgoing
  reasons, we affirm the juryâ€™s finding of liability on the bad faith cause of
  action, affirm the $150,000 compensatory damages award, and remit the $15 million
  punitive damages award to $10 million.Â  
WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] The addendum was not signed.Â  However, the record strongly supports the conclusion
  that Stephens was the author, a fact that Fortis neither admitted nor denied.
[2] Stephens had a similar conversation with Mitchellâ€™s
  insurance agent, who called to inquire about the rescission at the request of
  Mitchellâ€™s mother.Â  Stephens explained that Mitchell had misrepresented a pre-existing
  condition on his application form, and provided no information regarding
  Mitchellâ€™s right to an appeal.Â Â Â  
[3] This notation was in error, as Mitchell was HIV positive, and did not have
  AIDS.Â Â  
[4] Â Fortis eventually reinstated Mitchellâ€™s policy on May 27, 2004, well after the
  litigation had begun.
[5] Deborah Poston, an employee of Carolina, testified
  that when Mitchellâ€™s counsel notified her on March 8, 2004 that there might be
  an error on one of the records, she reviewed the medical chart and determined
  that there was a discrepancy in the date.Â  Poston testified that it took her
  â€œfive minutesâ€ to verify the correct date.Â  She further indicated that all
  records are kept chronologically, and that the misdated note was included with
  2002 medical records.Â  Other contextual clues included Mitchellâ€™s age on the
  note, which indicated he was eighteen (he would have been seventeen in 2001),
  the corresponding day and month with the other records from Dr. Chandlerâ€™s
  office, and Dr. Sheaâ€™s referral summary, which Fortis claimed it did not have
  but Mitchell alleged was in the file.Â  
[6] Mitchell introduced evidence that forty-five other cases were
  considered with Mitchellâ€™s in a single two-hour meeting.Â  Mitchell thus argued
  that it was unlikely that the committee spent more than three minutes on any
  one case, including Mitchellâ€™s.Â Â  
[7] We observe that this analysis adequately encompasses - and obviates the need
  for - the first four factors of the Gamble review, which include the
  defendantâ€™s degree of culpability, the duration of the conduct, the defendantâ€™s
  awareness or concealment, and the existence of similar past conduct.Â  
[8] We caution that trial courts must be careful about considering the
  net worth of the defendant.Â  Wealth cannot justify an otherwise unconstitutional
  punitive damages award.Â  Campbell, 538 U.S. at 427.Â  While the
  ability to pay remains relevant to the post-judgment due process review, a punitive
  damages award should never be based solely on a percentage of the defendantâ€™s net
  worth.Â  
[9] These humble verdicts appear quaint in light of todayâ€™s multimillion dollar
  awards.Â  Nevertheless, it helps to keep in mind that this $1,000 punitive
  damages award was imposed for breach of a contract involving only $155 in life
  insurance, paid at a weekly premium of 25 cents.
[10] Fortis is correct to observe that most of South Carolinaâ€™s
  punitive damages awards have been on the low end of the single-digit-ratio spectrum.Â 
  That does not mean the constitution requires this to be so.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Pete S. Bryant, Respondent,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Orangeburg County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26719
Submitted December 4, 2008 - Filed
  September 14, 2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Molly
  Crum, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Appellate
  Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of
  Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  KITTREDGE:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari
  to review the grant of post-conviction relief (PCR) to Pete S. Bryant.Â  On
  December 11, 1997, Bryant was convicted of armed robbery.Â  Because Bryant had
  â€œprior conviction[s]â€ for armed robbery, he was sentenced to life without
  parole under section 17-25-45 of the South Carolina Code.Â  The PCR court ruled
  that Bryant was not subject to a life without parole sentence and vacated the
  sentence.Â  We reverse.
I.
On
  December 27, 1996, at approximately 1:30 p.m., while armed with a pistol,
  Bryant and accomplices robbed the E-Z Shop BP Station in Orangeburg County, South Carolina.Â  The next day, December 28, around 2:00 a.m., Bryant and accomplices committed
  a second armed robbery of a convenience store, this time in Colleton County.Â  On December 29, shortly before midnight, Bryant and accomplices committed a
  third and final armed robbery in Jasper County.Â  In early January 1997, Bryant
  was arrested and charged with three armed robberies.
Bryant
  pled guilty on July 8, 1997, to the armed robberies in Colleton and Jasper Counties and was sentenced to ten years in prison.Â  On December 11, 1997, Bryant was
  convicted of the Orangeburg County armed robbery.Â  The trial court sentenced
  Bryant to life without parole in light of its reading of sections 17-25-45 and 17-25-50
  of the South Carolina Code.Â  Trial counsel failed to challenge the courtâ€™s
  construction of these statutes.Â  Bryantâ€™s direct appeal was affirmed by the
  court of appeals. Â State v. Bryant, Op. No. 99-UP-654 (S.C. Ct. App.
  filed Dec. 21, 1999).
II.
Bryantâ€™s
  initial application for PCR in 2000 was denied.Â  In 2003, this Court held in State
    v Gordon, 356 S.C. 143, 154, 588 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2003) that sections
  17-25-45 and 17-25-50 â€œmust be construed together in determining whether crimes
  committed at points close in time qualify for a recidivist sentence.â€ Â The Gordon Court applied its decision retroactively.Â  Id. at 155 n.12, 588 S.E.2d
  111 n.12.
Based
  on Gordon, Bryant filed the current PCR application in 2004 alleging
  ineffective assistance of counsel for failing to challenge the trial courtâ€™s
  interpretation of sections 17-25-45(F) and 17-25-50.Â  Bryant asserted at the
  PCR hearing that he was not a â€œcareer criminal,â€ the armed robberies were not
  â€œisolated,â€ and the robberies constituted â€œone string of events.â€Â  The PCR
  court agreed and granted relief.Â  The PCR court referenced Gordon and
  found that â€œall the Applicantâ€™s armed robbery offenses stemmed from a single criminal
  incident and were committed so closely in point of time as to be treated as one
  offense under S.C. Code Ann. Section 17-25-50 (Supp. 2004).â€
The
  State petitioned for a writ of certiorari, which we granted.
III.
An
  appellate court â€œwill reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision when it is controlled by
  an error of law.â€ Â Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222,
  225 (2000).Â  As this case involves statutory interpretation, we are presented
  with a question of law.Â  See Catawba Indian Tribe of S.C. v. State, 372
  S.C. 519, 524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007) (â€œThe issue of interpretation of a
  statute is a question of law for the court.â€).
â€œThe
  primary rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and give effect to the
  intent of the legislature.â€Â  Mid-State Auto Auction of Lexington, Inc. v.
    Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996).Â  A statute should be
  read as a whole.Â  Id.Â  Further, â€œ[s]tatutes which
  are part of the same legislative scheme should be read together.â€Â  Great
    Games, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 339 S.C. 79, 84, 529 S.E.2d 6, 8 (2000).Â  â€œUnless there is something in the statute requiring a
  different interpretation, the words used in a statute must be given their
  ordinary meaning.â€Â  Mid-State Auto, 324 S.C. at 69, 476 S.E.2d at
  692.
IV.
The
  resolution of this case requires the Court to examine the legislative history
  of section 17-25-45, scrutinize the interplay between subsection (F) of section
  17-25-45 and 17-25-50, and revisit Gordon, in light of the 2006
  amendment to section 17-25-45(F).
For
  the reasons discussed below, we adhere to that part of Gordon holding sections
  17-25-45(F) and 17-25-50 must be construed together, as section 17-25-50
  operates in some situations to preclude the imposition of a life without parole
  sentence.Â  356 S.C. at 154, 588 S.E.2d 111.Â  We overrule Gordon insofar
  as its assessment of legislative intent concerning sections 17-25-45(F) and
  17-25-50.Â  356 S.C. at 153-54, 588 S.E.2d at 110-11.
Specifically,
  referring to sections 17-25-45 and 17-25-50, a majority of this Court in Gordon stated â€œthe recidivist statute is aimed at career criminals, those who have been
  previously sentenced and then commit another crime.â€ Â 356 S.C. at 154, 588
  S.E.2d at 111.Â  Gordon further concluded that â€œ[t]he purpose of
  requiring separate offenses is to ensure that those offenders being sentenced
  under the harsh provisions of a recidivist sentencing statute have not been
  classified as habitual offenders because of multiple convictions arising from a
  single criminal enterprise.â€ Â Id. at 154, 588 S.E.2d at 110-11 (quoting State
    v. Benjamin, 353 S.C. 441, 446, 579 S.E.2d 289, 291 (2003) (Waller, J.,
  dissenting)).
A.
Section 17-25-45(F)
In
  the abstract, the policy rationale of the majority in Gordon is entirely
  defensible.Â  But the desired policy of the Gordon majority is at odds
  with the unambiguous language in section 17-25-45(F).Â  We do not make this
  finding lightly, for we recognize that a rigid application of section
  17-25-45(F), standing alone, would lead to harsh results. Our perception of the
  potential for harsh results, however, serves as no license to construe the
  statute in a manner inconsistent with its clear language.Â  Moreover, as
  addressed below, section 17-25-50 serves in most situations as a meaningful
  safeguard to the perceived unfair imposition of a life without parole sentence.
The view
  of the Gordon majority is, we believe, best understood by looking to the
  predecessor to section 17-25-45(F).Â  In 1982, the Legislature repealed former
  section 17-25-40 of the South Carolina Code (1976) and replaced it with section
  17-25-45.Â  The statute listed certain offenses and provided that â€œany person
  who has three convictionsâ€ shall be sentenced to life in prison.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(1)(A) (1985).Â  Of particular significance is the following
  provision:

	[A]
  conviction shall be considered a second conviction only if the date of the
  commission of the second crime occurred subsequent to the imposition of the
  sentence for the first offense.Â  A conviction shall be considered a third
  conviction only if the date of the commission of the third crime occurred
  subsequent to the imposition of the sentence for the second offense.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  17-25-45(1)(C) (1985).Â  The language of the 1982 statute fits well with policy
  notions set forth in Gordon of â€œhabitual offenders,â€ â€œmultiple criminal
  trials,â€ â€œmultiple convictions,â€ and â€œopportunities to understand the gravity
  of [oneâ€™s] behavior.â€ Â Gordon, 356 S.C. at 154, 588 S.E.2d at 111.
The
  1995 amendments to section 17-25-45 abandoned the necessity that a subsequent
  offense for enhancement purposes occur after imposition of the sentence for the
  prior offense.Â  The same is true with amendments subsequent to 1995.Â  Thus, while
  the Gordon rationale fits well with the 1982 legislation, those policy
  considerations are nowhere to be found in the prevailing statutory language,
  effective with the 1995 amendments.
In
  1996, when Bryant committed the armed robberies, subsection (F) provided:

	For the
  purpose of determining a prior conviction under this section only, a prior
  conviction shall mean the defendant has been convicted of a most serious or
  serious offense, as may be applicable, on a separate occasion, prior to the
  instant adjudication.

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(F) (Supp. 1995).
As noted, this
  Court decided Gordon in 2003, making a determination of legislative intent
  as to subsection (F).Â  In 2006, the Legislature amended section 17-25-45(F),
  and we believe the amendment was in response to Gordon on two fronts.Â 
  First, the Legislature confirmed the correctness of Gordonâ€™s holding
  that sections 17-25-45(F) and 17-25-50 must be construed together.Â  Second, the
  Legislature repudiated Gordonâ€™s reading of â€œa prior or previous
  conviction.â€

	For the
  purpose of determining a prior or previous conviction under this section and
    Section 17-25-50, a prior or previous conviction shall mean the defendant
  has been convicted of a most serious or serious offense, as may be applicable,
  on a separate occasion, prior to the instant adjudication.Â  There is no
    requirement that the sentence for the prior or previous conviction must have been
    served or completed before a sentence of life without parole can be imposed
    under this section.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(F)
  (Supp. 2008) (emphasis added).
Even
  in the absence of the second sentence added to subsection (F) in 2006, the
  statute provides that â€œa prior conviction shall mean the defendant has been
  convicted of a most serious or serious offense . . . on a separate occasion,
  prior to the instant adjudication.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(F) (Supp. 1995).Â 
  Bryantâ€™s situation falls squarely within the triggering language of section
  17-25-45(F), as it existed in 1996.Â  The last sentence in subsection (F), added
  in 2006, confirms the timing feature contained in the first sentence and
  repudiates Gordonâ€™s contrary interpretation. 
B.
Section 17-25-50

	Section
  17-25-50 states:
	In determining the number of offenses for
  the purpose of imposition of sentence, the court shall treat as one offense any
  number of offenses which have been committed at times so closely connected in
  point of time that they may be considered as one offense, notwithstanding under
  the law they constitute separate and distinct offenses.

While
  section 17-25-45(F) lends Bryant no support, the outcome of this case turns on
  the meaning of section 17-25-50â€™s phrase
  â€œso closely connected in point of time that they may be considered as one
  offense.â€Â  We acknowledge the â€œso closely connected in point of timeâ€ language
  in section 17-25-50 may become ambiguous as applied to certain situations.Â 
  When construing statutes forming part of the same legislative scheme, we must
  examine the statutes together as a whole.Â  Accordingly, when we read the
  unambiguous timing feature of â€œa prior convictionâ€ under section 17-25-45(F)
  alongside section 17-25-50, we construe the language of section 17-25-50 to
  preclude a life without parole sentence when the multiple offenses are
  inextricably connected and share an immediate temporal proximity.
State
  v. Woody, 359 S.C. 1, 596 S.E.2d 907
  (2004) illustrates a proper application of section 17-25-50 to preclude a life
  without parole sentence.Â  Woody was convicted of second-degree burglary and had
  two prior convictions for armed robbery.Â  Id. at 2, 596 S.E.2d at 907.Â  The
  State sought to use both armed robbery convictions for enhancement purposes and
  a life without parole sentence.Â  Id.Â  The Stateâ€™s position was rejected
  because the armed robberies constituted, as a matter of law, one offense for
  purposes of section 17-25-50.Â  Id. at 4, 596 S.E.2d at 908.Â  The two
  armed robberies arose from a single
  incident at the same time and at the same locationâ€”a robbery of the storeâ€™s
  clerk and the store itself.Â  Id. at 2, 596 S.E.2d at 907.
In Koon
  v. State, 372 S.C. 531, 534, 643 S.E.2d 680, 682 (2007), this Court held a
  burglary committed on March 28th of a different building and a different
  location clearly constituted a separate offense from burglaries occurring two
  weeks prior on March 13th and March 14th.Â  Due to this determination, it was
  not necessary for this Court to determine if the March 13th and March 14th burglaries
  were so closely connected to constitute one offense. Â Today we address the
  question left unanswered in Koon.
Our
  assessment of legislative intentâ€”multiple offenses inextricably connected and
  sharing an immediate temporal proximityâ€”will not provide a sure answer in every
  circumstance.Â  Because the â€œso closely connected in point of timeâ€ language in
  section 17-25-50 may become ambiguous in some situations, it necessarily
  follows that section 17-25-50 does not lend itself to a bright-line rule.Â  This
  Court so held in Koon.Â  When a genuine ambiguity exists as a
  result of the proposed application of section 17-25-50 to a given situation,
  the rule of lenity requires
  that the doubt must be resolved in the
  defendantâ€™s favor. Â State v. Blackmon, 304 S.C. 270, 273, 403 S.E.2d 660,
  662 (1991) (recognizing the settled rule that penal statutes must be strictly
  construed in the defendantâ€™s favor); see also United States v. Shabani, 513 U.S. 10, 17 (1994) (observing that
  the rule of lenity â€œapplies only when, after consulting traditional canons of statutory
  construction, we are left with an ambiguous statuteâ€). Â Bifulco v. United
    States, 447 U.S. 381, 387 (1980) (â€œ[T]he â€˜touchstoneâ€™ of the rule of lenity
  â€˜is statutory ambiguity.â€™â€).
We
  find no ambiguity concerning the application of section 17-25-50 to Bryantâ€™s
  multiple armed robberies over several days.Â  Bryant committed the three separate
  armed robberies on different days, at different locations, and the robberies
  involved different victims.Â  These separate and distinct crimes over a several
  day period were not inextricably connected and did not share an immediate
  temporal proximity.Â  Thus, Bryantâ€™s multiple armed robberies may not, as a
  matter of law, be considered â€œone offenseâ€ under section 17-25-50.
We
  emphasize that the determination of the number of prior convictions under
  section 17-25-45(F) must be made in conjunction with the section 17-25-50 â€œone
  offenseâ€ safeguard.Â  Cases involving the life without parole statutory scheme
  tend to raise the specter of two concerns.Â  First, without the link between
  sections 17-25-45(F) and 17-25-50, troubling issues would arise from the timing of the adjudications when a defendant is arrested and charged with multiple
  serious offenses.Â  Assuming a defendant is adjudicated guilty, disposing of all
  charges at the same time will avoid the application of section 17-25-45(F) as
  it relates to those charges and preclude a life without parole sentence.Â  This
  is so even if the offenses, if adjudicated separately, would otherwise require
  a life without parole sentence.Â  Conversely, disposing of the charges at
  different times would result in a life without parole sentence, unless the â€œone
  offenseâ€ provision of section 17-25-50 operates to foreclose a life sentence.Â 
  It would be an unsettling policy that allows the state to manipulate the timing
  of the adjudications of guilt to pursue a life without parole sentence.Â  Hence
  the importance of section 17-25-50â€™s â€œone offenseâ€ safeguard.
This
  leads to the second concern.Â  The language of section 17-25-50 is ambiguous
  when applied to certain situations.Â  The imprecise language, â€œso closely
  connected in point of time that they may be considered as one offense,â€ does
  not remove in every situation the potential for manipulating the timing of the adjudications.Â 
  As with Bryantâ€™s multiple and separate armed robberies, the applicability or
  nonapplicability of section 17-25-50 may be readily apparent in most
  circumstances.Â  Nevertheless, section 17-25-50â€™s imprecise language will
  continue to generate uncertainty in some situations.Â  Pending clarification
  from the Legislature, we earnestly attempt today to discern legislative intent.
V.
In
  sum, we hold: (1) section 17-25-45 operates to trigger a life without parole
  sentence under the respective â€œtwo-strikesâ€ and â€œthree-strikesâ€ provisions; (2)
  subsection (F) of section 17-25-45 sets forth a straightforward timing feature
  for identifying â€œa prior conviction;â€ and (3) section 17-25-50 is intended to
  serve as a legislatively sanctioned safeguard to ensure that a life without
  parole sentence is not imposed in cases where the multiple section 17-25-45
  offenses are â€œso closely connected in point of time that they may be considered
  as one offense,â€ Â which we construe to mean the offenses are inextricably connected
  and share an immediate temporal proximity.Â  In essence, what may be charged as
  two, three or more strikes under section 17-25-45 must be deemed â€œone-strikeâ€
  for sentencing purposes under section 17-25-50 and, as a result, preclude a
  life without parole sentence.Â  We believe this approach most closely hews to
  legislative intent based on what is admittedly imprecise statutory language.
We
  reverse the grant of PCR to Bryant.
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., concurs. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion. BEATTY
  dissenting in a separate opinion in which WALLER, J., concurs.

JUSTICE PLEICONES: I concur in Justice Kittredgeâ€™s decision to reverse
  the grant of post-conviction relief to respondent as I continue to believe that State v. Benjamin, 353 S.C. 441, 579 S.E.2d 289 (2003) was correctly
  decided and should apply to persons such as respondent who received an LWOP
  sentence pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 prior to the amendment of Â§
  17-25-45 (F), effective July 1, 2006.Â  Further, I concur in his analysis of the
  impact of the 2006 amendment on the interplay between Â§ 17-25-45 and S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 17-25-50 on cases arising after the effective date of that amendment.

JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  I disagree with the
  majorityâ€™s analysis of the import of the Legislatureâ€™s 2006 amendment to
  section 17-25-45(F).Â  In my view, this amendment does not call into question
  the Gordon decision or its expression of legislative intent.
Section
  17-25-45(F) recognizes Gordonâ€™s requirement that it should be read
  together with section 17-25-50.Â  To do so does not mean section 17-25-45(F)
  should be read to the exclusion of section 17-25-50; nor does it mean that
  section 17-25-50 acquired a new meaning or should be interpreted differently.Â 
  These sections should be interpreted in a manner that gives effect to both.Â 
  This may be accomplished by recognizing that section 17-25-45 focuses on how to determine a prior conviction and section 17-25-50 focuses on how a
  conviction should be treated for sentencing purposes under certain circumstances.
The
  issue in this case is the same as in Gordon; that is the correct
  interpretation of section 17-25-50.Â  Section 17-25-50 is unquestionably
  ambiguous in its use of the language â€œ. . . committed at times so closely
  connected in point of time that they may be considered as one offense . . . .â€Â 
  There is no requirement under section 17-25-50 that multiple offenses occur at
  the same time or in the same transaction.Â  Yet, the majority injects a
  contemporaneous transactional requirement though none is found in either
  section 17-25-45(e) or section 17-25-50 and is unnecessary to effectuate the
  intent of either section.
The
  Legislature has had ample opportunity since Gordon to further clarify
  section 17-25-50 but has not done so.Â  Thus, it would appear that Gordonâ€™s
  interpretation of legislative intent is correct.Â  The Legislatureâ€™s focus is
  recidivism, and flexibility in interpreting â€œclose in timeâ€ is necessary to
  give effect to legislative intent.Â  In Gordon, the multiple offenses
  took place over a period of seven days.Â  Here, the offenses took place during a
  period of fifty-four hours.Â  Assuming an LWOP sentence is inappropriate under
  the facts of the instant case, Bryant would still be exposed to multiple,
  maximum consecutive sentences.

I
  would affirm.
WALLER,
  J., concurs.

CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This case presents two
  questions that arise out of a dispute over church property and corporate
  control: (1) whether the trial court correctly determined that a trust deed,
  executed in 1745 for the establishment of a Parish in the Waccamaw Neck region
  of South Carolina,[1] remains valid; and (2) whether the trial court correctly determined that the
  vestry representing a minority group of the congregation were the officers of
  the congregationâ€™s corporate entity, All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Underlying this
  appeal are two lawsuits that were consolidated for trial in Georgetown County.Â  The first lawsuit (â€œthe 2000 Actionâ€) was a declaratory judgment action
  filed by All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc. against the Episcopal Church in the United States of America (â€œECUSAâ€) and the South Carolina Diocese (â€œDioceseâ€).Â  The 2000
  Action was precipitated by the Dioceseâ€™s recording of a notice with the
  Georgetown County clerk of court by which it purported to put the public on
  notice that the congregation of All Saints Parish held its property in trust
  for the Diocese and ECUSA.Â  
After
  the congregation fractured, the second lawsuit (â€œthe 2005 Actionâ€) was filed by
  a minority faction of the original congregation against its majority which had
  voted to sever ties with the ECUSA and the Diocese.Â  The minority faction
  remained loyal to the denominational authorities and was represented by a
  vestry led by Guerry Green (â€œthe minority vestryâ€).Â  The majority group was
  represented by a vestry led by W. Russell Campbell (â€œthe majority vestryâ€).Â  In
  the 2005 Action, the minority vestry sought a declaration that they, and not
  the majority vestry, were the officers of All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.Â 
  The 2000 Action and the 2005 Action were consolidated and tried in March 2006.Â 
  This appeal is from the trial courtâ€™s order.Â Â Â  
The
  facts relevant to this appeal date to the early eighteenth century.Â Â  By the
  Church Act of 1706, the South Carolina Commons House of Assembly (â€œCommons
  Houseâ€) established the Church of England as the official religion of colonial
  South Carolina and created the first parishes in the colony. Â Parishes were regionally
  defined and served as ecclesiastical and political entities.Â  All Saints
  Parish, however, was not formed at that time.Â  
In
  1734, George Pawley, a member of the Commons House, was appointed by
  legislative enactment to erect church buildings in the St. Johnâ€™s and the Prince
  George Parishes.Â  He was â€œauthorized to accept and take any grant or conveyance
  of any lands within said parishes respectively, to them and their heirs, in
  trust, for the inhabitants of said parishes.â€Â  Act No. 567 at Â§ 6, 3 S.C. Stat.
  374, 375 (1734).Â  In 1745, Percival and Ann Pawley transferred approximately 60
  acres to George Pawley and William Poole.Â  The language of this trust deed
  (â€œthe 1745 Trust Deedâ€) provided that George Pawley and William Poole were
  deeded the land â€œforever in Trust For the Inhabitants On Waccamaw Neck for Use
  of A Chapel or Church for divine Worship of the Church of England established
  by Lawâ€¦â€.Â  Consideration for this transfer was â€œthe Sum of one hundred pounds
  current Money of South Carolina.â€[2]Â 
  The terms of the 1745 Trust Deed did not bestow any duties upon the trustees,
  and there is no evidence to suggest that the trustees exercised any duties
  relative to the 1745 Trust Deed.Â  
On
  December 10, 1766, the inhabitants of the Waccamaw Neck formally petitioned the
  Commons House requesting the establishment of their own parish.Â  In 1767, an
  Act of the Commons House carved out a piece of the Prince George Parish, thus
  creating a new Parish named All Saints in the Waccamaw Neck region.Â 
  Subsequently, on January 2, 1767, the 1745 Trust Deed was recorded in Charleston.[3] Â By 1774, both George Pawley and William Poole had died.Â  Neither the 1745 Trust
  Deed nor the trusteeâ€™s wills named a successor trustee.Â  By all accounts, the
  property at issue has been actively used as a place of worship since at least
  1767, if not before.Â  
The relationship
  between South Carolinaâ€™s colonial parishes and the Diocese of London was
  severed during the Revolutionary War.Â  Nonetheless, the South Carolina General
  Assembly re-established All Saints Parish in 1778.Â  Even though the Church of
  England was formally disestablished as the official religion of South Carolina in 1790, the property at issue continued to be used as a place of worship.Â  
Â In
  1820, the South Carolina General Assembly passed an Act which officially
  incorporated the wardens and the vestry of All Saints Parish.Â  The Act
  expressly enabled the congregation to â€œhave, hold, take and receiveâ€ both real
  and personal property.Â  The congregationâ€™s incorporation was only effective for
  a period of fourteen years.Â Â  In 1839, the South Carolina General Assembly
  renewed the incorporation for an additional fourteen years and, in 1852, the
  General Assembly did so indefinitely.
An
  1880 Act of the South Carolina General Assembly established that title to any
  property belonging to inactive Episcopal corporations, churches, or dormant
  parishes was held in trust by the Trustees of the South Carolina Episcopal
  Diocese.Â  The record makes clear that in 1902, due to the 1880 Act, the All
  Saints congregation became concerned over the status of their incorporation and
  the status of title to church property.Â  Evidence in the record also indicates
  that this concern was exacerbated by the destruction of certain property
  records in a â€œgreat storm.â€Â  
In
  May 1902, as a result of its concern, the congregation asked the Diocese to
  â€œcooperate with [them] in having the charter of th[e] Parish renewed.â€Â  The
  Dioceseâ€™s Chancellor responded positively and not only suggested that the
  congregation formally incorporate with the Secretary of State as a South
  Carolina eleemosynary corporation, but also indicated that the Diocese would
  execute a quit-claim deed transferring to the congregation any interest the
  Diocese may have had in the All Saints property.Â Â Â  Â Â 
Therefore,
  at the direction of the Diocese, the congregation re-incorporated in 1902 under
  the name â€œAll Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.â€Â  Shortly thereafter, in 1903, the
  Trustees of the Diocese signed a quit-claim deed (hereinafter the â€œ1903
  Quit-Claim Deedâ€) transferring any interest the Diocese may have had in the congregationâ€™s
  property to All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc. Â The Diocese did not retain any
  interest in the property, reversionary or otherwise.Â  The 1903 Quit-Claim Deed
  was recorded in the Georgetown County public records on May 30, 1903.Â  
In
  1987, the Diocese amended its constitution and canons so as to include the
  â€œDennis Canon.â€Â  The Dennis Canon purports to declare a trust, in favor of the
  ECUSA and the Diocese, on all real and personal property held by any
  congregation.[4]Â 
  No such property canons existed in 1902 when the Diocese directed the
  congregation to incorporate, or when it executed the 1903 Quit-Claim Deed in
  favor of the newly created All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc. 
In
  August 2000, due to concern over the status of title to its property, the All
  Saints congregation conducted a formal title examination.Â  The examiner
  concluded that the 1745 Trust Deed and the 1903 Quit-Claim Deed were the only
  recorded deeds pertaining to the congregationâ€™s property.Â  Soon thereafter, in
  September 2000, the Diocese recorded a notice in Georgetown County purporting
  to declare that the congregation held its property, pursuant to the Dennis
  Canon, in trust for the benefit of the ECUSA and the Diocese (â€œthe 2000 Noticeâ€).Â 
  Because of the 2000 Notice and the 1745 Trust Deed, the congregation was unable
  to acquire title insurance.
In
  October 2000, the congregation, in the name of its corporate entity, All Saints
  Parish, Waccamaw, Inc., filed a declaratory judgment action against the ECUSA
  and the Diocese in which it sought an order declaring that the congregation
  held title to its property or, in the alternative, held its property in trust
  for the benefit of the inhabitants of the Waccamaw Neck pursuant to the 1745 Trust
  Deed.Â  The Diocese and the ECUSA answered and counterclaimed asserting that the
  property was subject to their canons and the 2000 Notice.Â  
By
  consent order, a guardian ad litem was appointed to represent the
  interests of John and Jane Doe, the unknown heirs of the original trustees to
  the 1745 Trust Deed, George Pawley and William Poole.Â  The Does and the
  congregation filed joint motions for summary judgment. Â The motions were
  granted and, pursuant to the 1745 Trust Deed, the trial court found that the
  Does held legal title to the property at issue and that the inhabitants of the
  Waccamaw Neck held equitable title as beneficiaries to the 1745 Trust Deed.Â 
  The matter was remanded to the probate court for further fact finding with
  respect to the identity of the parties to the 1745 Trust Deed.
The
  ECUSA and Diocese appealed.Â  The court of appeals found that there were genuine
  issues of material fact concerning whether the trust created by the 1745 Trust
  Deed failed when the Church of England ceased to be established as the official
  religion of South Carolina and whether the Statute of Uses operated to execute the
  trust.Â  Accordingly, the court of appeals remanded the case to the circuit
  court. Â All Saints Parish, Waccamaw v. The Protestant Episcopal Church in
    the Diocese of South Carolina, 358 S.C. 209, 595 S.E.2d 253 (Ct. App. 2004),
  cert denied, July 2005. 
In
  August 2003, prompted by events that are not relevant here, the congregation appointed
  a committee to recommend whether it should leave the Diocese and the ECUSA.Â  On
  December 9, 2003 the committee recommended that the corporate charter of All
  Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc. be amended so as to delete references to the
  canons and rules of the Diocese and the ECUSA.Â  Specifically, the committee
  recommended that â€œArticle Fourthâ€[5] of the 1902 Certificate of Incorporation be amended to read:

  The
    purpose of All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc., also known as All Saints Church,
    is to create an environment in which all people and especially the inhabitants
    of the Waccamaw Neck come to know Jesus Christ: to Love Him, to Worship Him, to
    Learn of Him, to Proclaim Him, and to Minister in His Name.Â Â Â  

Furthermore, the committee
  recommended that the congregation additionally amend its charter so as to
  affirmatively sever its affiliation with the ECUSA and the Diocese.Â  
On
  December 17, 2003, after learning of the proposed amendments, Edward L. Salmon,
  Jr., Bishop of the Diocese, sent a letter to the congregationâ€™s wardens and
  each member of the vestry stating that the congregationâ€™s status was reduced from
  that of a parish to a â€œmission.â€Â  In his letter, Bishop Salmon also declared that
  the members of the congregationâ€™s vestry had abandoned their offices.[6]Â  
On
  December 21, 2003, sixty members of the congregation signed a â€œRequest for
  Special Congregational Meeting.â€Â  The purpose of this meeting was to discuss
  and vote on whether the congregation should take the committeeâ€™s recommendations
  and vote to amend its charter so as to change its corporate purpose and sever
  its affiliation with the ECUSA and the Diocese.Â  Â Â Notice of the meeting was
  sent to the congregationâ€™s members on December 23, 2003.Â  
On
  January 8, 2004, five-hundred and seven of the congregationâ€™s members attended
  the Special Congregational Meeting and more than a two-thirds majority voted to
  amend the congregationâ€™s 1902 Certificate of Incorporation adopting the
  aforementioned amendment to â€œArticle Fourth.â€Â  Additionally, more than a
  two-thirds majority voted to amend the charter so as to withdraw from the
  Diocese and the ECUSA, but remain part of the Anglican Communion by affiliating
  themselves with the Episcopal Church of Rwanda and its Anglican Mission in America.[7]Â 
  Accordingly, the corporate secretary for All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.
  prepared and signed the Articles of Amendment to the 1902 Certificate of
  Incorporation.Â  These Articles of Amendment were filed in the South Carolina
  Secretary of Stateâ€™s office on January 15, 2004. 
On
  January 9, 2005, a small group of members who remained loyal to the Diocese and
  the ECUSA met with Bishop Salmon and purported to elect a new vestry for the
  congregation - the minority vestry.Â  Subsequently, on January 16, 2004, the
  majority group of members re-elected the vestry removed by the Bishop - the
  majority vestry.Â  Â Â 
On
  January 20, 2005, the minority vestry filed the 2005 Action against the majority
  vestry alleging that they forfeited office by recommending that the
  congregation sever its affiliation with the ECUSA and the Diocese.Â  The minority
  vestry sought a declaration that they were All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.â€™s
  true officers.Â  Additionally, they sought the return of the congregationâ€™s real
  and personal property.Â  The Diocese and Bishop Salmon joined in the action.Â 
  Subsequently, the trial court consolidated the 2000 Action and the 2005
  Action.Â  
The
  consolidated cases were tried and, after each of the parties presented its
  case, the trial court decided both underlying actions as a matter of law.Â  With
  respect to the 2000 Action, the trial court held that, pursuant to the terms of
  the 1745 Trust Deed, legal title to the real property remained in the unknown
  Heirs of George Pawley and William Poole, while beneficial title was possessed
  by the â€œinhabitants of Waccamaw Neck.â€[8]Â 
  As to the 2005 Action, the trial court held that members of the minority vestry
  were the true officers of All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.Â  In its original
  bench order, however, the trial court declined to eject the majority group from
  the real property because the identity of the parties to the trust created by
  the 1745 Trust Deed was yet to be determined by the probate court.Â  Nonetheless,
  upon a motion for reconsideration, the trial court ordered the Secretary of
  State to cancel the Articles of Amendment filed by the majority group, ejected
  the majority vestry from the property it occupied which was not granted to the
  congregation by the 1745 Trust Deed, and restrained the majority vestry from
  acting as the officers of All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.Â  
QUESTIONS PRESENTED
This
  Court granted certiorari to review the decision of the trial court and the
  parties raise the following issues for review:

  
    I. 
    Did the trial court err in holding
  that the trust created by the 1745 Trust Deed remains valid?
  
  
  
    II. 
    Did the trial court err in holding
  that members of minority vestry were the corporate officers of All Saints
  Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.?
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Because the trial court made its ruling on the 2000
  Action pursuant to Rule 39(b), SCRCP, the standard of review with respect to
  the 2000 Action is the same as that for an action at law tried without a jury.Â 
  In an action at law tried without a jury, the judgeâ€™s finding of fact will not
  be disturbed unless there is no evidence to support the courtâ€™s finding.Â  Jowers
    v. Hornsby, 292 S.C. 549, 552, 357 S.E.2d 710, 711 (1987).Â  
The standard of
  review for the grant of a directed verdict applies to the review of the 2005
  Action.Â  When reviewing a denial of a motion for directed verdict, this Court
  applies the same standard as the trial court.Â  Gadson ex rel. Gadson v. ECO
    Services of South Carolina, Inc., 374 S.C. 171, 175, 648 S.E.2d 585, 588
  (2007).Â  In ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is
  required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn
  therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion.Â  Hurd
    v. Williamsburg County, 363 S.C. 421, 426, 611 S.E.2d 488, 491 (2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
In
  this case, we are called upon to adjudicate two disputes.Â  The 2000 Action is a
  dispute between a congregation and its denomination over title to church
  property.Â  The 2005 Action is a dispute among the congregationâ€™s members over
  corporate control.Â  Because church disputes are very often prompted by
  disagreements over religious doctrine and belief, the civil courts in this
  country have addressed them carefully, keeping the First Amendment in mind.Â  The
  decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States concerning church dispute
  litigation make clear that there is no constitutionally prescribed rule for a
  civil courtâ€™s disposition of such matters.Â  Nonetheless, there is a general
  constitutional command, based in the First Amendment, mandating that civil
  courts Â â€œdecide churchâ€¦disputes without resolving underlying controversies over
  religious doctrine.â€Â  Serbian Eastern Orthodox Diocese v. Milivojevich,
  426 U.S. 696, 710 (1976).Â  
Within
  the context of this general constitutional command, the Supreme Court of the United States has expressly approved two methods for a civil courtâ€™s resolution of church
  disputes.Â  These approaches have become known as the â€œdeference approachâ€ and
  the â€œneutral principles of law approach.â€Â  We hereby explicitly reaffirm that,
  when resolving church dispute cases, South Carolina courts are to apply the neutral
  principles of law approach as approved by the Supreme Court of the United
  States in Jones v. Wolf, 443 U.S. 595 (1979), and expressed by this
  Court in Pearson v. Church of God, 325 S.C. 45, 478 S.E.2d 849 (1996).Â 
  The following context is necessary for a clear understanding of this rule and
  its application to the facts presented by this case.
The
  Supreme Court of the United States first approved the â€œdeference approachâ€ in
  1871.Â  See Watson v. Jones, 80 U.S. 679 (1871).Â  Under this approach, a
  court must only determine whether a church is â€œcongregationalâ€ or
  â€œhierarchicalâ€ in nature.[9]Â 
  If the church is congregational, the court will resolve the dispute by deferring
  to a majority of the congregation.Â  However, if the congregation at issue is
  part of a hierarchical organization, the court will defer to the decision of
  the ecclesiastical authorities.Â  
Because
  the deference approach was, for a long time, the only approach explicitly
  approved as constitutional by the Supreme Court of the United States, this Court has issued a handful of opinions that are consistent with the deference
  approach.Â  See Bramlett v. Young, 229 S.C. 519, 93 S.E.2d 873
  (1956) (holding that a minority group of a local,
  hierarchical Presbyterian churchâ€™s members were entitled to ownership and
  control of church property because they were recognized as the true
  congregation by the hierarchical authorities);Adickes v. Adkins,
  264 S.C. 394, 215 S.E.2d 442 (1975) (holding that where a majority of a local
  Presbyterian congregation voted to sever its connection with its hierarchical
  authorities, the minority faction which the hierarchical authorities recognized
  as the true congregation was entitled to control of the church properties); Seldon
    v. Singletary, 248 S.C. 148, 326 S.E.2d 147 (1985) (holding that a local
  church was part of a hierarchical denomination, thus, the minority group of
  members recognized by the hierarchical authorities were entitled to possession
  and control of church property).Â  In each of these cases we applied the deference
  approach and analyzed the issues by determining whether the church at issue was
  congregational or hierarchical in nature and deferred accordingly.Â  This short
  analysis disposed of those cases and, in so doing, these decisions complied
  with the First Amendmentâ€™s command that â€œcivil courtsâ€¦decide church property
  disputes without resolving underlying controversies over religious doctrine.â€[10]Â  Serbian Eastern Orthodox Diocese v. Milivojevich, 426 U.S. 696, 710 (1976) quoting Presbyterian Church v. Hull Church, 393 U.S. 440, 449 (1969).Â  
The
  deference approach, which the Supreme Court of the United States never
  explicitly held was the only constitutional method of adjudicating church
  disputes, is rigid in its application and does not give efficacy to the neutral,
  civil legal documents and principles with which religious congregations and
  denominations often organize their affairs.Â  Thus, throughout the country,
  other approaches to the resolution of church disputes have slowly
  developed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In
  1979, the Supreme Court of the United States expressly approved the use of a
  second method of resolving church disputes.Â  In Jones v. Wolf, the
  Supreme Court affirmed a Georgia courtâ€™s use of the neutral principles of law
  approach to resolve church disputes.Â  443 U.S. at 603 (holding that a state is
  constitutionally entitled to adopt the neutral principles of law approach as a
  means of adjudicating church disputes).Â  This method â€œrelies exclusively on
  objective, well-established concepts of trust and property law familiar to
  lawyers and judges.Â  It thereby promises to free civil courts completely from
  entanglement in questions of religious doctrine, polity, and practice.â€Â  Id. at 603.Â  Church disputes that are resolved under the neutral principles of law
  approach do not turn on the single question of whether a church is
  congregational or hierarchical.Â  Rather, the neutral principles of law approach
  permits the application of property, corporate, and other forms of law to
  church disputes.Â  
A
  clear recitation of the neutral principles of law approach as adopted by this
  Court was enunciated in Pearson v. Church of God.Â  In Pearson, we
  articulated the rule that South Carolina civil courts must follow when
  adjudicating church dispute cases.Â  We reaffirm and more fully explain this
  rule here.Â  The Pearson rule provides: 

  (1)
    Courts may not engage in resolving disputes as to religious law, principle,
    doctrine, discipline, custom, or administration; (2) courts cannot avoid
    adjudicating rights growing out of civil law; (3) in resolving such civil law
    disputes, courts must accept as final and binding the decision of the highest
    religious judicatories as to religious law, principle, doctrine, discipline,
    custom, and administration.Â  

325 S.C. at 53, 478 S.E.2d at
  854.Â  
The Pearson rule establishes that where a civil court can completely resolve a church
  dispute on neutral principles of law, the First Amendment commands it to do
  so.Â  Nonetheless, where a civil court is presented an issue which is a question
  of religious law or doctrine masquerading as a dispute over church property or
  corporate control, it must defer to the decisions of the proper church
  judicatories in so far as it concerns religious or doctrinal issues.Â  See Serbian
    Eastern Orthodox Diocese, 426 U.S. at 709 (finding that the
  controversy before the Court â€œessentially involve[d] not a church property
  dispute, but a religious dispute the resolution of whichâ€¦is for ecclesiastical
  and not civil tribunals.â€). Â Â 
It
  is with the Pearson rule in mind that we now turn to the two issues
  before us in this appeal. Â We remain mindful of the First Amendment and its protections
  of religious liberty. Â Nonetheless, adjudication of this matter does not
  require us to wade into the waters of religious law, doctrine, or polity.Â  Â Â We
  find that the Diocese and ECUSA organized their affairs with All Saints Parish
  in a manner that makes the complete resolution of the questions presented achievable
  through the application of neutral principles of property, trust, and corporate
  law. 
I. Property Ownership
Turning
  to the 2000 Action, the trial court held that the trust created by the 1745
  Trust Deed remained valid and that legal title is held by the unknown heirs of
  George Pawley and William Poole while the beneficial title is held by the â€œInhabitants
  of Waccamaw Neck.â€Â  We disagree.Â  
Based
  upon an application of the relevant neutral principles of law, we hold that the
  trial court erred in determining that the trust created by the 1745 Trust Deed
  remains valid.Â  Further, we hold that this trust was executed by the Statute of
  Uses and that title to the property is held by the congregational corporate
  entity - All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.Â  
A.   The Statute of Uses
It
  is well established that â€œwhere there is a conveyance to one for the use of
  another, and the trustee is charged with no duty which renders it necessary
  that the legal estate should remain in him to enable him properly to perform
  such duty, the Statute of Uses executes the use and carries the legal title to
  the [beneficial] use.â€Â  Faber v. Police, 10 S.C. 376, 389-90 (1877).[11]Â Â  Further, in a trust where the trustees have no duties,
  â€œthe legal and equitable titles are merged in the beneficiaries and the
  beneficial use is converted into legal ownership.â€Â  Johnson v. Thornton,
  264 S.C. 252, 257, 214 S.E.2d 124, 127 (1975).Â  Nonetheless, the Statute of
  Uses will not operate to execute a trust where there is no beneficiary capable
  of taking legal title.Â  See Bowen v. Humphreys, 24 S.C. 452, 455 (1886)
  (holding that the Statute of Uses cannot execute a trust where there is no
  identifiable beneficiary capable of holding title).Â  
Therefore, there are two questions that must be asked in order to
  determine if the trust created by the 1745 Trust Deed was executed by the
  Statute of Uses: (1) whether the trustees had any duties relative to their
  office, and (2) whether there is a beneficiary capable of taking title.Â  We
  hold that the trustees of this trust did not have any duties relative to their
  office and that the congregation of All Saints Parish was the intended
  beneficiary and, upon its formation, was clearly capable of taking title.Â  
1. Trusteesâ€™ Duties
We
  hold that the 1745 Trust Deed did not impose any duties upon the trustees,
  George Pawley and William Poole.Â  Pawley and Poole were colonial appointees
  given the authority to accept conveyances of land for the purpose of establishing
  parishes.Â  When named trustees to the 1745 Trust Deed, they were acting as
  appointees of the colony, not as trustees with traditional duties.Â  This
  conclusion is supported by the relevant legal realities of that time.Â  The
  court of appeals in All Saints correctly stated that â€œin colonial times,
  churches could not be recognized by the government until they owned property,
  and they could not own property until they had been officially recognized.â€Â  All
    Saints, 358 S.C. at 225, 595 S.E.2d at 262.Â  â€œAs such, a colonial practice
  arose in which a settlor placed property in trust for a congregation until such
  a time as the government recognized the church.â€Â  Id. (citing Town of
    Pawlett, 9 U.S. (Cranch) at 330 (holding â€œno parish churchâ€¦could
  have legal existence until consecration and consecration was expressly
  inhibited unless a suitable endowment of land.â€)).Â  Pawley and Poole did not have any duties relative to the trust, but simply acted as custodians of the
  property at issue until All Saints Parish was officially established.Â  This
  conclusion is supported by language of the 1745 Trust Deed which did not
  expressly impose any duties upon them, nor is there any evidence in the record
  which suggests that either of the trustees performed any acts relative to their
  office as trustee. 
Further,
  Percival and Ann Pawley were not traditional settlors of a trust.Â  Rather, they
  sold the property at a price far above nominal value.Â  They were clearly
  sellers of property to colonially appointed commissioners for the establishment
  of a parish, purposes specified by the colonial government.
2. Beneficiary Capable of
  Taking Title
Holding
  that the trustees to the 1745 Trust Deed had no duties, we now analyze whether
  there was a beneficiary capable of taking title.Â  According to the terms of the
  1745 Trust Deed, the beneficiaries were â€œthe Inhabitants of Waccamaw Neck.â€Â  This
  term is ambiguous and parol evidence should be used to ascertain its meaning. Â See Shelley v Shelley, 244 S.C. 598, 606, 137 S.E.2d 851, 855
  (1964)(holding that parol evidence is admissible so long as its admission is
  merely intended to explain and apply what the settlor has written). Â Â 
Based
  on the following application of parol evidence, we hold that the term
  â€œInhabitants of Waccamaw Neckâ€ was used by the settlors of the trust as an
  expression referring to the yet-to-be-created All Saints Parish.Â  Early South Carolina colonial statutes used the term â€œinhabitantsâ€ when referring to the colonyâ€™s
  parishes.Â  For instance, The Church Act of 1706 contains multiple uses of the
  term â€œinhabitantsâ€ referring to parishes.Â  SeeÂ  Act No. 256 at Â§Â§ 7, 10,
  12, 13, 19, 21, 22, 29, 30, 35, 2 S.C. Stat. 284-89 (1706).Â  Additionally, this
  understanding of the term is supported by the historical context in which the
  1745 Trust Deed was executed.Â  In 1745, the inhabitants of Waccamaw Neck were
  parishioners of Prince Georgeâ€™s Parish.Â  They were clamoring for the
  establishment of their own Parish congregation and had already been worshipping
  on the land at issue for approximately eight years. Â It was within this
  historical context that the 1745 Trust Deed was executed in expectation that
  the subject property would be for the benefit of the yet-to-be formed All
  Saints Parish.Â  Â 
Additionally,
  according to the express terms of the original Church Act of 1706, a colonial Parish
  could hold title to land.Â  The Act specifically empowered commissioners â€œto
  take up by grant from the Lords Proprietors, or purchase the same for them, or
  any other person, and have, taken and receive so much land as they think
  necessary for the several sites of the several churches.â€Â  Act No. 256 at Â§ 8,
  2 S.C. Stat. 284.Â  Thus, when the Church Act of 1767 formed All Saints Parish,
  the Statute of Uses operated to execute the trust created by the 1745 Trust
  Deed and title vested in the intended beneficiary, the congregation of All
  Saints Parish.Â  
B. 1903 Quit-Claim Deed
Moreover,
  the 1903 Quit-Claim Deed makes clear that All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.
  holds title to its property.Â  The All Saints Parish congregation was officially
  incorporated in 1820.Â  In 1902, due to doubt over the status of the
  congregationâ€™s incorporation, the Diocese directed it to re-incorporate as â€œAll
  Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.â€Â  Shortly thereafter, in order to settle any
  doubt as to the status of title to Parish property, the Diocese voluntarily
  executed the 1903 Quit-Claim deed. The 1903 Quit-Claim Deed makes clear that
  title to the property at issue is currently held by the congregationâ€™s
  corporate entity - All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.Â Â Â Â  
C. 2000 Notice and Dennis
  Canon
Furthermore,
  we hold that neither the 2000 Notice nor the Dennis Canon has any legal effect
  on title to the All Saints congregationâ€™s property.Â  A trust â€œmay be created by
  either declaration of trust or by transfer of propertyâ€¦.â€Â  Dreher v. Dreher,
  370 S.C. 75, 80, 634 S.E.2d 646, 648 (2006).Â  It is an axiomatic principle of
  law that a person or entity must hold title to property in order to declare
  that it is held in trust for the benefit of another or transfer legal title to
  one person for the benefit of another.Â  The Diocese did not, at the time it
  recorded the 2000 Notice, have any interest in the congregationâ€™s property.Â 
  Therefore, the recordation of the 2000 Notice could not have created a trust
  over the property.
For
  the aforementioned reasons, we hold that title to the property at issue is held
  by All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc., the Dennis Canons had no legal effect on
  the title to the congregationâ€™s property, and the 2000 Notice should be removed
  from the Georgetown County records.
II. Corporate Control
Turning
  to the 2005 Action, we find that the trial court applied the deference
  approach, determined that the congregation was part of a hierarchical
  organization, and deferred to the Dioceseâ€™s ecclesiastical authorityâ€™s determination
  that members of the minority vestry were the true officers of All Saints
  Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.Â  We disagree.
While
  it is true that â€œ[c]ourts may not engage in resolving disputes as to religious
  law, principle, doctrine, discipline, custom, or administration,â€ Pearson,
  325 S.C. at 53, 478 S.E.2d at 854, the resolution of the 2005 Action does not
  require such judicial meddling.Â  The 2005 case turns on a determination of
  whether the Articles of Amendment approved by the members of All Saints
  Waccamaw, Inc. on January 8, 2004 were adopted in compliance with the South
  Carolina Non-Profit Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-31-1001, et. seq.Â  We
  find that the Articles of Amendment were lawfully adopted and effectively
  severed the corporationâ€™s legal ties to the ECUSA and the Diocese.Â  Therefore,
  we find that the members of the majority vestry are the true officers of All
  Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc.Â  
Pursuant
  to the South Carolina Non-Profit Act, a religious corporation may amend its
  Articles of Incorporation to add or change a provision permitted in the
  articles or delete a provision not required in the articles. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  33-31-1001.Â  Amendment to a corporationâ€™s articles, to be adopted, must be
  approved by (1) the board of directors, (2) the members â€œby two-thirds of the
  votes cast or a majority of the voting power, whichever is less,â€ and (3) any
  person whose approval is required by the Articles of Incorporation.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 33-31-1003(a)(1-3).Â  The passage of the Articles of Amendment approved
  by the congregation on January 8, 2004 complied with all three of these
  requirements.Â  
First,
  the Articles of Amendment were approved by the board of directors.Â  On December
  8, 2003, while still in good standing with the Diocese, the majority vestry,
  acting as the corporationâ€™s board of directors, approved the Articles of
  Amendment at issue here.Â  Thus, the passage of the Articles of Amendment met
  the requirements of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-31-1003(a)(1).
Second,
  the Articles of Amendment were approved by the members of All Saints Parish,
  Waccamaw, Inc. by two-thirds of the votes cast.Â  Five hundred and seven members
  of All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc. were present at the January 8, 2004
  meeting which was called to discuss and vote upon the Articles of Amendment.Â 
  Of the five hundred and seven members present, four hundred and sixty-four
  votes were cast in favor of amending the Articles of Incorporation.Â  Therefore,
  more than nine-tenths of the votes cast were in favor of the amendments,
  clearly more than the two-thirds statutorily required.Â  There is no evidence in
  the record to suggest that the members present and voting were not in good standing
  at the time of the vote.Â  Thus, the passage of the Articles of Amendment
  clearly met the requirements of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-31-1003(a)(2).Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Finally,
  nothing in the All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc. by-laws or the Constitutions
  and Canons of the ECUSA or Diocese requires third-party approval for amendments
  to the congregationâ€™s corporate charter, therefore the congregationâ€™s adoption
  of the Articles of Amendment complied with the requirements of S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  33-31-1003(a)(3).Â  The statutory provisions pertaining to a religious
  corporationâ€™s amendment of its corporate charter were amended in 1994 so as to
  add the option of third-party approval.Â  See 1994 S.C. Acts 384.Â  There
  is no evidence in the record that, since that time, the Diocese has ever
  attempted to gain approval power over amendments to the All Saints Parish,
  Waccamaw, Inc. corporate charter.Â  
The
  facts presented by this case demonstrate that the congregation, in compliance
  with relevant statutory provisions and applicable bylaws, passed the Articles
  of Amendment, thus removing any reference to the ECUSA and Diocese and
  explicitly severing any legal relationship with those organizations.Â 
  Therefore, through the application of neutral principles of law, it is clear to
  us that the true officers of All Saints Parish, Waccamaw, Inc. are the members
  of the majority vestry.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision with respect to both the 2000
  Action and the 2005 Action.
WALLER, BEATTY,
  JJ., Acting Justice James E. Moore and Acting Justice Perry M. Buckner, concur.

[1] The Waccamaw Neck is a geographical area bounded by the Waccamaw River and Winyah Bay on the west and south, the Atlantic Ocean on the east, and the North Carolina line in the north.
[2] According to the â€œAverage Earnings Index,â€ one hundred (100) British Pounds in
  1745 was worth One Hundred Forty-One Thousand, Eight Hundred Twenty-Five
  (141,825) British Pounds or Two Hundred Seventy-Seven Thousand, Seven Hundred
  and Seventy-Eight (277,778) U.S. Dollars in 2007. 
[3] At the time, Charleston was the only place in South Carolina at which land instruments could be recorded.Â  
[4] Presumably, the Dennis Canon was enacted in reaction to the Supreme Court of
  the United Statesâ€™s opinion in Jones v. Wolf, 443 U.S. 595 (1979).Â  In Jones,
  the Supreme Court established that the First Amendment did not require a civil
  court to defer completely to ecclesiastical authorities when adjudicating
  church disputes.Â  Â Â 
[5] Prior to the amendment, â€œArticle Fourthâ€ read: â€œThe purpose of the said
  proposed Corporation is to conduct Religious services, and prosecute religious
  works under the forms and according to the canons and rules of the protestant
  Episcopal Church, and as a component part of the Diocese of said Church in South Carolina.â€
[6] In his letter, Bishop Salmon did not opine as to the status of the
  congregationâ€™s members in so far as it concerned their ability to meet and vote
  on corporate action.Â Â Â  
[7] The Anglican Communion is the worldwide body of Episcopal Dioceses.Â  The
  Episcopal Church of Rwanda is the Rwandan equivalent of the United Statesâ€™ ECUSA.Â Â  
[8] The trial court made its ruling on the 2000 Action pursuant to Rule 39(b),
  SCRCP.Â  
[9] â€œA congregational church is an independent organization, governed solely within
  itselfâ€¦, while a hierarchical [or ecclesiastical] church may be defined as one
  organized as a body with other churches having similar faith and doctrine with
  a common ruling convocation or ecclesiastical head.â€Â  Seldon v. Singletary,
  284 S.C. 148, 149, 326 S.E.2d 147, 148 (1985).Â  
[10] This command applies to state courts by way of the Fourteenth Amendment.
[11] England enacted the Statute of Uses during the reign of Henry VIII.Â  27 Henry
  VIII ch. 10 (1535).Â  It was adopted by the South Carolina Commons House of
  Assembly in 1712.Â  Act No. 322, 2 S.C. 401 (1712) at 466.Â
