THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Jonathan Kyle
          Binney, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Cherokee County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26723
  Heard June 24, 2009 - Filed September 21,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Emily
          C. Paavla, of Center for Capital Litigation, of Columbia, and John H. Blume, of
          Ithaca, NY, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney GeneralÂ  John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Â Senior Assistant Attorney General
          William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia, and Harold W. Gowdy, III, of
          Spartanburg; Â for Respondent.
        JohnÂ 
          Nichols, of Bluestein, Nichols, Thompson & Delgado, of Columbia; Kathy Lynn
          Osborn and Mary Kristin Glazner, both of Indianapolis, IN, for Amicus Curiae Professors
          of Legal Ethics.
        Joseph
          L. Savitz, III and Robert M. Dudek, both of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Appellate Defense.
        Ernest
          Charles Grose, Jr., of Greenwood, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Public
          Defenders Association.
        FrankÂ 
          Eppes, of Greenville, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Trial Lawyerâ€™s
          Association.
        C.
          Rauch Wise, of Greenwood, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Association of
          Criminal Defense Lawyers.
        Cecil
          Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Amicus Curiae Solicitorâ€™s Association.
      
    
  

___________
CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, we granted a writ of certiorari to
  review an order of the post-conviction relief (PCR) court denying Petitionerâ€™s
  motion for (1) the return of his trial file from the Attorney Generalâ€™s Office
  (AGO) and (2) the disqualification of the AGO attorneys who viewed the file. Â Petitioner
  argues that his attorney-client privilege was violated when, after he filed an
  application for PCR, trial counsel turned over his entire trial file to the AGO.[1] Â We find that Petitionerâ€™s attorney-client privilege was not violated by the
  disclosure of his entire trial file to the AGO and affirm the PCR courtâ€™s
  order.Â 
Facts/Procedural History
Petitioner was convicted of
  murder and first degree burglary, and he was sentenced to death.Â  We affirmed
  Petitionerâ€™s conviction and sentence.Â  State v. Binney, 362 S.C. 353,
  608 S.E.2d 418 (2005), cert denied, 546 U.S. 852 (2005).Â  
On April 7, 2006, after his
  execution was stayed, Petitioner filed an application for PCR in which he
  alleged that trial counsel was ineffective during the guilt and sentencing
  phases of his trial.Â  Petitioner alleged many grounds of ineffectiveness.Â  In
  particular, three of the allegations were so broad as to encompass effectively
  the entire scope of trial counselâ€™s obligations in Petitionerâ€™s defense.Â 
  First, Petitioner alleged that â€œ[trial] counsel failed to investigate the facts
  and circumstances surrounding the death of the victim.â€Â  Second, Petitioner
  alleged that â€œ[trial] counsel failed to investigate, develop, and present all
  available, relevant, and admissible mitigating evidence.â€Â  Third, Petitioner
  alleged that â€œ[trial] counsel failed to investigate and present evidence in
  support of all potential defenses in the guilt and innocence phase.â€Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On February 27, 2007, trial
  counsel met with attorneys from the AGO.Â  The purpose of this meeting was to
  discuss the allegations made by Petitioner in his application for PCR.Â  Due to
  the breadth of Petitionerâ€™s allegations of ineffectiveness, trial counsel
  determined that it was necessary to make an entire copy of the trial file
  available for review and copying by the AGO attorneys.Â  
Petitioner later discovered
  that trial counsel made the entire trial file available to the AGO.Â  Petitioner
  moved the PCR court to order that his file be returned and that the AGO
  attorneys who reviewed the file be disqualified from participating in his PCR
  proceedings, arguing that his attorney-client privilege had not been waived as
  to the entire file.Â  Following a hearing, the PCR court denied Petitionerâ€™s
  motion finding that the broad allegations of ineffective assistance of counsel
  contained in Petitionerâ€™s PCR application waived the attorney-client privilege
  with respect to all material contained in the trial file.Â  
Petitioner filed a notice of
  appeal and a petition for a writ of certiorari to review the order of the PCR
  court.Â  The PCR courtâ€™s denial of Petitionerâ€™s motion is interlocutory, and
  thus not immediately appealable.Â  Nonetheless, due to the exceptional
  circumstances of this matter, we granted Petitionerâ€™s writ of certiorari to
  review the following issue:

  Given
    the particular allegations made in his April 7, 2006 application for PCR, did
    Petitioner completely waive his attorney-client privilege with respect to his
    trial file? 

Standard of Review
If the PCR courtâ€™s findings
  are supported by any evidence of probative value in the record, they should be
  upheld.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626
  (1989).Â  Â Â 
Law/Analysis
Petitioner argues that he did
  not completely waive his attorney client privilege upon application for PCR
  and, therefore, this privilege was violated when trial counsel made his entire
  file available to the AGO.Â  We disagree.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-130
  (1996), which describes a PCR applicantâ€™s waiver of the attorney-client
  privilege, states in pertinent part:

  Where a
    defendant alleges ineffective assistance of prior trial counselâ€¦as a ground for
    post-conviction reliefâ€¦the applicant shall be deemed to have waived the
    attorney-client privilege with respect to both oral and written communications
    between counsel and the defendant, and between retained or appointed experts
    and the defendant, to the extent necessary for prior counsel to respond to the
    allegation.Â  This waiver of the attorney client privilege shall be deemed
    automatic upon the filing of the application alleging ineffective assistance of
    prior counsel and the court need not enter an order waiving the privilege.Â 
    Thereafter, counsel alleged to have been ineffective is free to discuss and
    disclose any aspect of the representation with representatives of the State for
    purposes of defending against the allegations of ineffectiveness, to the extent
    necessary for prior counsel to respond to the allegation.Â  

â€œIn
  interpreting statutes, th[is] Court looks to the plain meaning of the statute
  and the intent of the Legislature.â€Â  Gay v. Ariail, 381 S.C. 341, 344, 673 S.E.2d 418, 420 (2009) (citing State
    v. Dingle 376 S.C. 643, 659 S.E.2d 101 (2008)).Â  Furthermore,Â  

  If possible, legislative intent should be found in the
    plain language of the statute itself.Â  If a statuteâ€™s language is plain and
    unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning, the rules of statutory
    interpretation are not needed and the Court has no right to impose another
    meaning.

Id.Â  (citing State v. Gaines, 380 S.C. 23, 667 S.E.2d
  728 (2008)).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
We find that the language of S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-130 (1996) is plain and unambiguous.Â  Section 17-27-130
  clearly states that an applicantâ€™s â€œwaiver of the attorney client privilege
  shall be deemed automatic upon the filing of the application alleging
  ineffective assistance of prior counselâ€¦.â€Â  In so far as it applies to this
  case, we find that Petitionerâ€™s waiver of the attorney-client privilege was
  automatic upon the filing of his application for PCR on April 7, 2006. Â In order to determine the scope of a PCR applicantâ€™s
  waiver pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-130 (1996), the specific allegations
  made in the initial application are controlling.Â  Due to the automatic nature
  of this waiver, its scope cannot be whittled down by the subsequent amendment
  of the application.[2] Â Â 
Furthermore, Â§ 17-27-130
  states that an applicantâ€™s waiver is made â€œto the extent necessary for prior
  counsel to respond to the allegation.â€Â  It is clear from the language of this
  provision that the General Assembly did not intend for the scope of this waiver
  to be entirely limited or automatically complete.Â  We find that the plain
  language of Â§ 17-27-130 makes clear that the General Assembly intended for the
  scope of the automatic waiver to be directly proportional to the breadth of the
  allegations made in each individual PCR application.Â  
Turning to the facts of this
  case, upon application, Petitioner waived his attorney-client privilege â€œto the
  extent necessary for prior counsel to respond to the allegation[s]â€ of ineffectiveness.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-130 (1996).Â  We find that the particular allegations
  made in Petitionerâ€™s application for PCR were so broad as to effectuate a
  complete waiver of his attorney-client privilege.Â  
Although Petitionerâ€™s
  application alleged many grounds of ineffectiveness, we find that the breadth
  of three particular allegations constituted a complete waiver of Petitionerâ€™s
  attorney-client privilege.Â  Specifically, Petitionerâ€™s application alleges that
  trial counsel was ineffective because he failed to (1) â€œinvestigate the facts
  and circumstances surrounding the death of the victim,â€ (2) â€œinvestigate,
  develop, and present all available, relevant, and admissible mitigating
  evidence,â€ and (3) â€œinvestigate and present evidence in support of all
  potential defenses in the guilt and innocence phase.â€Â  The breadth of these
  allegations, which encompass in effect the entirety of trial counselâ€™s
  obligations in presenting a defense, necessitated a review of the entire trial
  file in order for the AGO, on behalf of trial counsel, to properly â€œrespond to
  the allegation[s]â€ in Petitionerâ€™s application.Â  
Finally, pursuant to the
  clear and unambiguous language of Â§ 17-27-130, prior counsel was justified in
  disclosing the entire trial file for reviewing and copying.Â  Section 17-27-130
  states, 

  [C]ounsel
    alleged to have been ineffective is free to discuss and disclose any aspect of
    the representation with representatives of the State for purposes of defending
    against the allegations of ineffectiveness, to the extent necessary for prior
    counsel to respond to the allegation.Â  

This provision permits prior
  counsel, when faced with extremely broad allegations of ineffectiveness, to provide
  representatives of the State with any information he deems necessary for the
  defense of his representation.Â  Under the specific facts of this case, prior
  counsel was justified in making Petitionerâ€™s entire trial file available to the
  AGO.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we rule that Petitioner
  completely waived his attorney-client privilege pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  17-27-130 because the allegations made in his application for PCR were so broad
  as to encompass in effect nearly the entire scope of trial counselâ€™s
  obligations in Petitionerâ€™s defense.Â  
WALLER, BEATTY and
  KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J. dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent, and would require the AGO to
  return trial counselâ€™s file, and would disqualify the AGO attorneys who viewed
  that file.
Under our post-conviction
  relief (PCR) statutes, subject to a limited number of exceptions not applicable
  here, an applicant must file an application within a one year statute of
  limitations or be barred from pursuing this form of collateral relief.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-40 through 50 (2003).Â  The overwhelming majority of these initial
  applications, including the one at issue here, are filed by the inmate pro
    se.Â  To hold, as does the majority, that the claims made in this
  uncounseled document determine, forever, the scope of the applicantâ€™s waiver of
  his attorney-client privilege is unsupported by the language of the statute. 
The majorityâ€™s opinion rests
  on its interpretation of Â§ 17-27-130, entitled â€œWaiver of attorney-client
  privilege by allegation of ineffective prior counsel, access to files.â€Â  In its
  entirety, this statute provides:

  Where a
    defendant alleges ineffective assistance of prior trial counsel or appellate
    counsel as a ground for post-conviction relief or collateral relief under any
    procedure, the applicant shall be deemed to have waived the attorney-client
    privilege with respect to both oral and written communications between counsel
    and the defendant, and between retained or appointed experts and the defendant,
    to the extent necessary for prior counsel to respond to the allegation.Â  This
    waiver of the attorney-client privilege shall be deemed automatic upon the
    filing of the allegation alleging ineffective assistance of prior counsel and
    the court need not enter an order waiving the privilege.Â  Thereafter, counsel
    alleged to have been ineffective is free to discuss and disclose any aspect of
    the representation with representatives of the State for purposes of defending
    against the allegations of ineffectiveness, to the extent necessary for prior
    counsel to respond to the allegation.
  In the
    case of a defendant who has been convicted of a capital offense and sentenced
    to death, the defendantâ€™s prior trial counsel or appellate counsel shall make
    available to the capital defendantâ€™s collateral counsel the complete files of
    the defendantâ€™s trial or appellate counsel.Â  The capital defendantâ€™s collateral
    counsel may inspect and photocopy the files, but the defendantâ€™s prior trial or
    appellate counsel shall maintain custody of their respective files, except as
    to the material which is admitted into evidence in any trial proceeding.

Reading the first
  paragraph of the statute, it is my opinion that the automatic waiver of the
  privilege does not extend to the entire file, but is instead limited to: â€œoral
  and written communications between counsel and the defendant, and between
  retained or appointed experts and the defendant,[3] toÂ  the extent necessary for prior counsel to respond to the
  allegationâ€¦.Thereafter, counsel alleged to have been ineffective is free to
  discuss and disclose any aspect of the representation with representatives of
  the Stateâ€¦to the extent necessary for prior counsel to respond to the
  allegation.â€Â  It is noteworthy that whileÂ  this paragraph makes no mention of
  counselâ€™s file, but insteadÂ  explicitly limits the permissible scope of
  counselâ€™s disclosures to AGO attorneys, it is upon this paragraph of the
  statute alone that the majority rests its holding.
The second paragraph of the
  statute does directly reference the attorneyâ€™s file, and is specifically
  directed to capital cases such as this.Â  This paragraph requires that the
  capital defendantâ€™s trial and/or appellate attorneys make files available to
  the defendantâ€™s PCR counsel who may inspect and copy the contentsÂ  but explicitly
  requires that the original attorneys otherwise retain custody of their files.Â 
  To hold, as does the majority, that under this statute these attorneys are free
  to turn over their entire files to the AGO is puzzling in light of the
  statuteâ€™s clear directive that the files are to remain in the custody of the
  original attorney, and be made available only to the applicantâ€™s attorney. Â I
  would not foreclose the possibility that an attorney charged with rendering
  ineffective assistance may need to rely upon an item in her file as part of her
  defense, but that is a far cry from copying the entire file and turning it over
  to the AGO. 
When the Court abolished the
  doctrine of in favorem vitae, it did so in large part in reliance upon
  the legislatureâ€™s adoption of the Uniform Post Conviction Relief Act.Â  State
    v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â  The decision today to hold
  that thisÂ  pro se capital defendant has made a wholesale
  waiver of his attorney-client privilege undermines one of the fundamental tenets
  upon which the abolition of the ancient doctrine rested, that is, that PCR
  â€œsafeguards the [capital defendant] and render[s] the protection afforded by in
    favorem vitae surplusage.â€Â  Id. at 61, 406 S.E.2d 324. 
I would reverse the circuit
  courtâ€™s order, require that the file be returned to trial counsel, and would
  disqualify any member of the AGOâ€™s staff who has viewed this file or any of its
  contents.Â  I respectfully dissent.


[1] The issue presented by this matter is novel and capable of arising in every PCR
  proceeding.Â  We granted a writ of certiorari in this case due to these
  exceptional circumstances.Â  See In re Breast Implant Product Liability
    Litigation, 331 S.C. 540, 503 S.E.2d 445 (1998); see also Laffitte v.
      Bridgestone Corp., 381 S.C. 460, 674 S.E.2d 154 (2009) (finding that, where
  a matter is not otherwise immediately appealable, this Court may issue a writ
  of certiorari due to â€œexceptional circumstancesâ€).Â  In Bridgestone, we
  â€œgranted a petition for a writ of certiorari in our original jurisdiction.â€Â  Bridgestone,
  381 S.C. at 464.Â  Writing for the Court in that matter as I do here, my
  statement of the procedural posture was incorrect.Â  A matter may not be before
  this Court by a writ of certiorari and in our original jurisdiction.Â 
  The questions presented by Bridgestone, just as the issue presented
  here, were before this Court by way of a writ of certiorari issued due to
  exceptional circumstances, and not in our original jurisdiction.Â Â Â Â Â  
[2] Petitioner amended his application for PCR on May 7, 2007 and May 25, 2007.Â  These
  amended applications are of no consequence in determining the degree to which
  Petitioner waived his attorney-client privilege.
[3] Note the statutory waiver does not extend to communications between the experts
  and the defendantâ€™s attorney.

          (Piedmont/Atlanta) LLC; George C. Beighley and Mason A. Summers, of Richardson
          Plowden & Robinson, P.A., for Petitioner Woolfson.
        Douglas F. Patrick and Stephen R.H. Lewis, of Covington, Patrick
          Hagins, Stern & Lewis, P.A., of Greenville; James Walter Fayssoux, Jr., and
          Paul S. Landis, of Anderson Fayssoux & Chasteen, of Greenville, for
          Respondents.
      
    
  

__________
PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioners have filed a petition for a
  writ of certiorari seeking review of an order of the circuit court allowing
  respondents to contact nonparty patients of petitioners.Â  We grant the
  petition, dispense with further briefing, and vacate the order of the circuit
  court.
This matter
  involves three actions filed against petitioners for medical malpractice,
  fraud, and breach of contract arising out of LASIK eye surgeries.Â  By order
  dated November 14, 2008, the circuit court compelled petitioners to respond to
  respondentsâ€™ discovery requests, including the production of the medical
  records of several nonparty patients treated at petitionersâ€™ facilities.Â  At
  the same time, a Protective Order was issued to prohibit the use of
  confidential information obtained through the medical records and to prohibit
  any person from contacting the nonparty patients or their medical providers.Â  Petitioners
  complied with the orders and provided unredacted copies of the medical records
  of the nonparty patients.
On February 17,
  2009, respondents filed a motion to modify the Protective Order to allow them
  to contact and interview nonparty patients of petitioners whose identity and
  medical records were disclosed pursuant to the November 14th order.Â 
  By order dated April 21, 2009, the circuit court found respondents were
  entitled to interview the nonparty patients subject to the privacy safeguards
  set forth in the Protective Order.Â  
Petitioners first
  sought a writ of certiorari to review the April 21st order.Â  This
  Court granted the petition for a writ of certiorari and remanded the matter to
  the circuit court to address whether the
  interviews with the nonparty patients were necessary to respondentsâ€™claims.Â  Hollman v. Woolfson,
  Op. No. 2009-MO-025 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed May 28, 2009).Â  

On remand, the circuit court
  found the interviews were necessary for respondentsâ€™
  fraud cause of action, Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA) cause of action, and
  in order for respondents to meaningfully respond to petitionersâ€™ defenses of
  the statute of frauds and the statute of repose.Â  Petitioners now seek
  another writ of certiorari to review the decision of the circuit court.Â  
A writ of certiorari may be
  issued to review a discovery order where exceptional circumstances exist.Â  Laffitte
    v. Bridgestone Corp., 381 S.C. 460, 674 S.E.2d 154 (2009).Â  This matter presents exceptional circumstances which warrant the
  issuance of a writ of certiorari.Â  Allowing the interviews will moot any claim
  petitioners could raise on appeal that the discovery was erroneously allowed.Â 
  In addition, the privacy rights of patients is an issue of significant public
  interest, and issues involving the release of patient information in discovery
  is arising more often in the courts.Â  Accordingly, we grant the petition for a
  writ of certiorari and dispense with further briefing.
On certiorari,
  this Court will review only errors of law and will not review factual findings
  unless wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  S.C. Bd. of Examâ€™rs in Optometry
    v. Cohen, 256 S.C. 13, 180 S.E.2d 650 (1971).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s rulings on
  discovery matters will not be disturbed by an appellate court absent a clear
  abuse of discretion.Â  Dunn v. Dunn, 298 S.C. 499, 381 S.E.2d 734 (1989). 
Rule 26(b)(1), SCRCP,
  provides, unless otherwise limited by order of the court, â€œ[p]arties may obtain
  discovery regarding any matter, not privileged, which is relevant to the
  subject matter involved in the pending action . . . It is not ground for
  objection that the information sought will be inadmissible at the trial if the
  information sought appears reasonably calculated to lead to the discovery of
  admissible evidence.â€Â  If the discovery process threatens to become abusive or
  create a particularized harm to a litigant or third party, the trial judge may
  issue an order â€œto protect a party or person from annoyance, embarrassment,
  oppression, or undue burden by expense.â€Â  Rule 26(c), SCRCP; Hamm v. S.C.
    Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 312 S.C. 238, 439 S.E.2d 852 (1994).Â  If a person
  requesting a protective order shows a particularized harm which will be caused
  by allowing the discovery, the opposing party has the burden of showing the
  information sought is â€œrelevant and necessaryâ€ to the case.Â  Laffitte v.
    Bridgestone Corp., supra; Hamm v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, supra.Â 
  In determining whether a protective order is necessary, the trial judge is
  required to weigh the factors of whether the information sought is â€œrelevant
  and necessaryâ€ evidence against any particularized harm the opposing party may
  suffer. Â Laffitte v. Bridgestone Corp., supra; Hamm v. S.C. Pub. Serv.
    Commâ€™n, supra.Â  In determining whether information is necessary, the party
  seeking the information must â€œdemonstrate with specificity exactly how the lack
  of information will impair the presentation of the case on the merits to the
  point that an unjust result is a real, rather than a merely possible, threat.â€Â  Laffitte v. Bridgestone Corp., 674 S.E.2d at 163.Â  The trial court must
  determine whether there are reasonable alternatives available to discover the
  information.Â  Id.
As to the requirement of
  particularized harm, no protective device can limit the invasion of the
  nonparty patientsâ€™ privacy once contact with them is permitted.Â  The nonparty
  patients have a valid and legitimate expectation that their medical information
  will remain confidential which outweighs respondentsâ€™ intent to use this
  personal information to buttress their claims by showing a propensity by
  petitioners for malpractice.Â  Petitioners have shown particularized harm to the
  nonparty patients which will arise if the interviews are permitted.Â  Both the
  State and Federal government have recognized the importance of the privacy
  rights of patients.Â  Therefore, respondents must show the information sought
  from the interviews is relevant and necessary to the case.
As to the requirement that the information sought be relevant, this
  Court has held the information must be specifically relevant to the issues
  involved in the litigation, not merely relevant to the subject matter of the
  litigation.Â  Lafitte v. Bridgestone Corp. supra.Â  
The circuit court judge found
  respondentsâ€™ â€œmethodology by which [they have] restricted its interview
  requests provides a substantial basis for the relevancy.â€Â  He found â€œthe
  ability to interview [the nonparty patients] and discuss their individual
  experiences at TLC along with those of [respondents] is relevant under Rule
  SCRCP 26 [sic] and permissible except to the extent that good cause exists to
  restrict discovery of this information and these witnesses.â€Â  The judge further
  found the information sought was directly related to the issues central to
  respondentsâ€™ malpractice claims.Â  He stated the discovery of other patients
  with problems and treatment similar to respondentsâ€™ problems is clearly relevant
  since a central issue in the malpractice claims is â€œthe applicable standard of
  care as it evolved during and after the time of [respondentsâ€™] surgeries.â€
A claim for malpractice
  requires a showing of the standard of care, a breach of the standard of care,
  proximate cause, and damages.Â  Doe
    v. Am. Red Cross Blood Servs., 297 S.C. 430, 377 S.E.2d 323 (1989). Â The standard of care which must be observed by a physician is that of
  an average, competent practitioner acting in the same or similar circumstances.Â  Id.
The evidence relating to
  treatment of the nonparty patients is irrelevant to respondentsâ€™ negligence claims
  in that it cannot be used to show petitioners breached the standard of care
  with a particular patient.Â  Â Â Accordingly, the circuit court erred in finding
  the interviews with the nonparty patients were relevant to the causes of action
  for malpractice.Â  Whether petitioners breached the standard of care with any
  patients other than respondents is irrelevant to whether petitioners were
  negligent in their treatment of respondents.
A cause of action for fraud
  requires: (1) a representation of fact; (2) its falsity; (3) its materiality;
  (4) either knowledge of the falsity of the representation or reckless disregard
  of its truth or falsity; (5) the intent that the representation be acted on;
  (6) the hearerâ€™s ignorance of the falsity of the representation; (7) the
  hearerâ€™s reliance on the truth of the representation; (8) the hearerâ€™s right to
  rely on the representation; and (9) the hearerâ€™s consequent and proximate
  injury.Â  Schnellmann v. Roettger, 373 S.C. 379, 645 S.E.2d 239 (2007).
There is no evidence that any
  of the nonparty patients were victims of fraud.Â  The treatment received by the nonparty patients is irrelevant to
  respondentsâ€™ causes of action for fraud.Â  Whether other patients were similarly
  treated does not prove any of the elements required to show fraudulent conduct
  by petitioners toward respondents.
To establish a cause of
  action under the UTPA, the plaintiff must prove unfair or deceptive acts or practices in
  the conduct of any trade or commerce.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-20(a)
  (1985).Â  The unfair or deceptive act or practice must affect the
  public interest.Â  Singleton v. Stokes Motors, Inc., 
  358
  S.C. 369, 595 S.E.2d 461 (2004).Â  An impact on the public interest may be shown if the acts or
  practices have the potential for repetition.Â  Id.Â  The
  potential for repetition may be proven by showing: (1) the same kind of actions
  occurred in the past, thus making it likely they will continue to occur absent
  deterrence; or (2) the defendantâ€™s procedures created a potential for
  repetition of the unfair and deceptive acts.Â  Id.
Although evidence of
  petitionersâ€™ treatment of nonparty patients could be relevant for the UTPA
  cause of action, as discussed below, the evidence is not necessary for
  respondents to establish that cause of action.
In determining whether
  information is necessary, the party seeking the information must â€œdemonstrate
  with specificity exactly how the lack of information will impair the
  presentation of the case on the merits to the point that an unjust result is a
  real, rather than a merely possible, threat.â€Â  Laffitte v. Bridgestone
    Corp., 674 S.E.2d at 163.Â  The trial court must determine whether there are
  reasonable alternatives available to discover the information.Â  Id. Â 
The circuit court found that
  respondents allege petitioners engaged in a corporate-wide scheme to conceal
  the harm done to respondents and other patients and to delay the disclosure of
  crucial information beyond the applicable statutes of limitations and/or
  repose.Â  The judge found the information sought from other patients is
  necessary because the alleged scheme is based on the institutional quality of
  petitionersâ€™ knowledge of the falsity of their representations and their
  knowledge that the representations would be relied on by a significant number
  of patients.Â  However, the circuit court failed to make specific findings as to
  how the lack of information would impair respondentsâ€™ case.Â  
Respondents may pursue their
  claims against petitioners without interviewing petitionersâ€™ nonparty
  patients.Â  Respondents failed to demonstrate with specificity what information
  they seek or how the lack of interviews with the nonparty patients will impair
  the presentation of their case to the extent that an unjust result is a real
  threat.Â  Further, there is no evidence that there are no other reasonable
  alternatives available to respondents to discover the information they seek
  from the nonparty patients.Â  
The circuit court committed
  an abuse of discretion in determining the interviews with the nonparty patients
  were necessary.Â  Petitionersâ€™ treatment of other patients is not necessary to
  establish any element of respondentsâ€™ causes of action.Â  In fact, no
  information obtained in the interviews could establish whether petitioners
  breached the standard of care when treating respondents or committed fraud on
  respondents.Â  As to the UTPA cause of action, the circuit court did not make a
  specific finding as to exactly how the lack of information obtained from the
  interviews would impair respondentsâ€™ presentation of the merits of that cause
  of action or that there were no reasonable alternatives available to discover
  the information.Â  Laffitte v.
    Bridgestone Corp., supra.Â 
  Accordingly, the record does not support the finding that the interviews are
  necessary for the UTPA cause of action.
Further, it would be
  inequitable to allow respondents to obtain nonparty patient information from
  petitioners with the understanding the patients would not be contacted, only to
  subsequently permit respondents to contact the patients.Â  Had the provision of
  the Protective Order prohibiting respondents from contacting petitionersâ€™
  patients not been included, there is a possibility petitioners would not have
  disclosed the patient records, would have sought to redact the records, and/or
  would have sought review of the order requiring the disclosure by writ of
  certiorari or by refusing to comply with the order and appealing a contempt
  citation.Â  Therefore, the order of the circuit court allowing respondents to
  interview the nonparty patients is
VACATED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Eddie Wayne
          Eldridge, Charles Louis Beaudrot, Russie Beaudrot Young, Bernard H. Padgett,
          Homer Charles Walker, and Ray F. Stewart, individually, and on behalf of a
          class of plaintiffs similarly situated, and Herbert Malcolm Crum,
          individually, and on behalf of a class of plaintiffs similarly situated, Petitioners, 
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        South Carolina
          Department of Transportation, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Greenwood County
  The Hon. Robert M. Erwin, Jr., Circuit
Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26726
  Heard May 28, 2009 - Filed September 21,
2009Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        J.
          Kendall Few, of Greer, Thomas E. Hite, Jr., of Hite & Pruitt, of Abbeville,
          for Petitioner.
        G.
          P. Callison, Jr., of Callison, Dorn, Thomason, Knott & Moore, of Greenwood,
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

___________
JUSTICE WALLER: We granted a writ of
  certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Eldridge v. Depâ€™t of
    Transp., Op. No. 2007-UP-351 (Ct. App. filed July 11, 2007), in which the
  Special Referee held Petitioners suffered no damages as the result of the
  taking of an abandoned right-of-way in downtown Greenwood; the Court of Appeals
  affirmed.Â  Â Â We reverse.
FACTS
This case
  concerns an abandoned railroad right-of-way in Greenwood, SC.Â  Petitioners are
  the current property owners along the right-of-way, and/or heirs of the
  original landowners at the time the right-of-way was acquired by the railroad.Â  
The railroad,
  located in downtown Greenwood, was originally acquired by Southern Railwayâ€™s
  predecessor by virtue of an 1845 Act.Â  Some 150 years later, in the 1980â€™s, the
  railroad elected to relocate its tracks to the outskirts of Greenwood.Â 
  Railroad attempted to convey its right-of-way to County by quitclaim deed.Â  Petitioners
  brought this action challenging the conveyance, claiming ownership to the
  right-of-way had reverted to them upon Railroadâ€™s abandonment.Â  Â Â 
After a long
  procedural battle, the Court of Appeals held title to the former right of way
  vested in the Plaintiffs, Petitioners herein.Â  Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 503 S.E.2d 191 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Petitioners consist of two
  classes of individuals: 1) abutting landowners along the right-of-way when the
  railroad tracks were removed in 1984, and 2) heirs to the original owners at
  the time the right-of-way was acquired in 1852.Â  Petitioners were granted class
  certification, and their takings claim was referred to the Special Referee.Â  
The sole issue
  before the Referee was the amount of damages suffered by Petitioners as a
  result of two projects in which Respondent, SCDOT, used the abandoned railroad
  right of way.Â  The first project was the 1986 Project, consisting of two main
  areas: 1) the portion of the right-of-way situated between two existing
  roadways (the Property Between The Roads); and 2) the property directly
  adjacent to the existing landowners (Adjacent Property).Â  The Adjacent Property
  consists of 55,605 square feet, while the Property Between the Roads consists
  of 102,372 square feet.Â  The second project was the Calhoun Road Project
  (eighteen tracts located within the abandoned right-of-way along Calhoun Road).Â  
The Referee
  awarded Petitioners damages for the taking of the Adjacent Property and the
  Calhoun Road Project.[1]Â 
  As to the Property Between the Roads, however, the Referee held the property had
  no value for compensation purposes inasmuch as it could not be used for
  on-premises identification signs.Â  Accordingly, Petitioners were awarded no
  damages for the taking of the Property Between the Roads.Â  The Court of Appeals
  affirmed the Special Refereeâ€™s order.Â  
ISSUE
Did the Court of
  Appeals err in affirming the Refereeâ€™s holding that the Property Between the
  Roads could not be used for on-premises identification signs?
ON-PREMISES SIGNS
The Property
  Between the Roads is essentially a median which runs through downtown
  Greenwood.Â  Petitioners contend the Referee and Court of Appeals erred in
  holding no signs could be placed on the Property Between the Roads.Â  We agree.
An â€œOn Premisesâ€
  sign is defined by Regulation as â€œany sign which is designed, intended or used
  to advertise or inform of the principal activity taking place, or the product
  being sold on the property where the sign is located.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann.
  Regs. 63-342 (Q) (Supp. 2006).Â Â Â  Â Â  
A 1986 Greenwood
  County ordinance states as follows:

  d) Permanent on premises identification signs for which a
    permit is required:Â  One (1) free-standing identification sign per lot for each
    100 feet, or fraction thereof of street frontage over 200 feet, provided said
    signs shall . . . be located no closer than 5 feet from the nearest property
    line. Â (Emphasis supplied).Â  

The Referee held
  an â€œon premisesâ€ sign is required to be located on the actual property where
  the business is located.Â  The Referee found the Property Between the Roads was
  not contiguous or adjacent to any land where businesses were located, because
  it is separated from any businesses by the existing roads.Â  The Court of
  Appeals affirmed, and went one step further, noting that the 1996 order of
  Judge Macaulay stated that â€œ[a]s to that portion of the former right-of-way
  covered by streets, highways, and sidewalks for more than 20 years . . ., the
  title lies in the City, County, and Highway Department.â€Â  Based upon the 1996
  order,Â  the Court of Appeals found SCDOT owns the portion of the land upon
  which the roads are situated,[2] such that the Property Between the Roads is physically separated from the business
  properties and is not contiguous, adjacent to, or adjoining such properties.Â  Eldridge
    v. Depâ€™t of Transp., Op. No. 2007-UP-351 (Ct. App. filed July 11, 2007). Â We
  find the Court of Appeals and Referee placed too strict a construction on the definition
  of â€œon premises.â€Â  
In Keane v.
  Hodge, 292 S.C. 459, 357 S.E.2d 193 (Ct. App. 1987), the Court of Appeals
  addressed a situation in which the Petitioners wished to erect a sign on their
  easement, and the Hilton Head Board of Adjustment revoked their sign permit on
  the ground that the easement was not appurtenant to the property it served,
  such that Petitionersâ€™ proposed sign was not â€œon premisesâ€ but off premises.Â 
  The Court of Appeals reversed, finding the easement was part of Petitionersâ€™
  property, such that the sign was in fact on premises.[3]Â Â Â Â  
In Keane,
  the Court of Appeals stated, â€œ[O]rdinances in derogation of natural rights of
  persons over their property are to be strictly construed as they are in
  derogation of the common law right to use private property so as to realize its
  highest utility and should not be impliedly extended to cases not clearly
  within their scope and purpose.â€Â  292 S.C. at 464, 357 S.E.2d at 196, citing
  Purdy v. Moise, 223 S.C. 298, 302, 75 S.E.2d 605, 607 (1953).Â Â  
More recently,
  however, this Court acknowledged that the term â€œcontiguousâ€ has been broadly
  interpreted.Â  Sonoco v. SC Depâ€™t of Revenue, 378 S.C. 385, 662 S.E.2d
  599 (2008), citing Kizer v. Clark, 360 S.C. 86, 90-91, 600 S.E.2d
  529, 532 (2004) (recognizing that marshlands and creeks do not defeat townâ€™s
  contiguity for annexation purposes); Mosteller v. County of Lexington,
  336 S.C. 360, 364-65, 520 S.E.2d 620, 623 (1999) (explaining the term
  â€œcontiguousâ€ and stating â€œâ€˜[a]butâ€™ means to be contiguous . . . [h]owever, abut
  does not always mean there must be actual contactâ€).Â  
In Sonoco,
  we went further and distinguished between â€œcontiguousâ€ in a lay or secondary
  sense, versus in legal contemplation, stating, â€œIn the legal field, it has been
  defined as: â€˜[i]n close proximity; neighboring; adjoining; near in succession;
  in actual close contact; touching at a point or along a boundary; bounded by or
  traversed by.â€™ Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 290 (5th ed.1979).â€Â  378 S.C. at 391, 662
  S.E.2d at 602.Â  Significantly, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-3-305 is also cited in Sonoco;
  it states, in part: 

  For purposes of this chapter, â€œcontiguousâ€ means property which is
    adjacent to a municipality and shares a continuous border.Â  Contiguity is not
    established by a road, waterway, right-of-way, easement, railroad track,
    marshland, or utility line which connects one property to another; however, if
    the connecting road, waterway, easement, railroad track, marshland, or utility
    line intervenes between two properties, which but for the intervening connector
    would be adjacent and share a continuous border, the intervening connector does
    not destroy contiguity.

In Sonoco,
  we ultimately held a taxpayerâ€™s office buildings were subject to property tax
  because the public road and railroad tracks did not defeat contiguity of the
  plant and office buildings.Â  We find the issue presented here is squarely
  controlled by our opinion in Sonoco; we find the contiguity requirement
  is met here such that for purposes of the applicable ordinance, the signs may
  be considered â€œon premises.â€Â Â  
Further support
  for this result is found in the definition of â€œadjacent.â€ Blackâ€™s Law
    Dictionary, 38 (5th Ed. 1979) defines it adjacent as â€œlying near or close
  to; sometimes, contiguous, neighboring.Â  Adjacent implies that the two objects
  are not widely separated, though they may not actually touch.â€Â Â  
We find the Court
  of Appeals and Referee unduly restricted the definition of â€œon premises.â€Â Â 
  Given the liberal construction afforded the definition of â€œcontiguityâ€ in Sonoco,
  we find the Property Between the Roadâ€™s separation by the roadway does not
  defeat contiguity, such that the signs may be considered â€œon premisesâ€ for
  purposes of the ordinance.Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appeals opinion is
  reversed, and the case is remanded to the Referee for calculation of damages.
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  BEATTY, J., and Acting Justice Timothy M. Cain, concur. PLEICONES, J.,
  dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  Because an intervening landowner
  separates the Property Between the Roads and the Adjacent Property, I would
  find that a sign placed on the former would not have constituted an
  â€œon-premises identification signâ€ under the Greenwood County ordinances.Â 
  Consequently, the Court of Appeals correctly upheld the determination of the
  special referee that the Property Between the Roads could not be used for
  identification signs.
In my view, neither Sonoco
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 378 S.C. 385, 662 S.E.2d 599 (2008), nor
  case law on municipal annexation are dispositive.Â  The special referee first
  invoked the word â€œcontiguousâ€ in attempting to determine whether a sign placed
  on the Property Between the Roads would be considered â€œon premisesâ€ of the
  Adjacent Property, for purposes of a Greenwood County Regulation.Â  The referee
  took the term from Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways and Pub.
    Transp., 287 S.C. 108, 336 S.E.2d 879 (Ct. App. 1985), which cited South
  Carolina Regulation 63-342(Z).Â  The Regulation provided in part:

  On-Premise
    Sign, shall consist of any outdoor sign, display, device, figure, painting,
    drawing, message, plaque, poster, billboard, or other thing which is designed,
    intended or used to advertise or inform of the activity taking place on the
    property where located, and any additional surrounding land which is under
    lease or is owned in fee simple and is specifically reserved for use by said
    activity.Â  Land considered for this purpose shall be contiguous with the land
    occupied by the commercial or industrial activity and shall not be connected by
    narrow bands or strips of land.Â  The area between the main building and the
    advertising device must be improved and landscaped in a suitable manner so as
    to portray a single unit.

25A
  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-342(Z) (1985).
In my view, the broad
  definition of â€œcontiguousâ€ developed in annexation statutes and case law is not
  relevant to and does not comport with the term as it was used in defining an
  â€œon-premiseâ€ sign.Â  Given that SCDOT holds title to the roadway separating the
  properties rather than a mere easement,[4] I would hold that a sign placed on the Property Between the Roads is not an
  â€œon-premises identification signâ€ of any business located on the Adjacent
  Property.
The dispute over this land
  began over two decades ago and I would take this opportunity to bring it to a
  close.Â  I would affirm the Court of Appeals.[5]


[1]Â  No appeal is taken as to these awards.
[2]Â  We concur in this holding.
[3]Â  SCDOT also cites Young v. SC
  Depâ€™t of Hwys and Public Transp., 278 S.C. 108, 336 S.E.2d 879 (Ct. App.
  1985).Â  Young, however, merely cites Regulation 63-342 for the
  proposition that â€œon-premise signs are located contiguous with the land
  occupied by the commercial or industrial activity.â€
[4] The Court of Appeals found that because Petitioners
  did not appeal from Judge Macaulayâ€™s 1996 order, it became the law of the
  case.Â  Eldridge v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., Op. No. 2007-UP-351
  (Ct. App. filed July 11, 2007).Â  The Court of Appeals interpreted the order as
  holding that SCDOT owns the portion of the land upon which the roads are
  situated.Â  Id.Â  On certiorari, Petitioners do not challenge the Court of
  Appeals interpretation of the order and it therefore must be accepted as the
  law of the case.Â  See ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte &
    Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997) (holding that an
  unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case).
[5] See Rule 220(c), SCACR (2008) (appellate court may affirm upon any
  ground appearing in the Record on Appeal).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Ivan N.
          Walters, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26728
Submitted August 24, 2009 - Filed September 28, 2009Â  

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Susan B. Hackett, Staff Attorney, both of
          Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Desa A.
          Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, the Office of
  Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the
  agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to a definite suspension from
  the practice of law for twelve months.Â  Respondent requests that the suspension
  be made retroactive to the date of his interim suspension, June 27, 2008.Â  In
    the Matter of Walters, 378 S.C. 596, 663 S.E.2d 482 (2008).Â  We accept the
  agreement and impose a definite suspension of twelve months, retroactive to the
  date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in the
  agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Matter I
From April 2003 through
  October 2004, respondent committed a felony in violation of 18 U.S.C. Â§ 4 in
  that, although he had knowledge of the actual commission of bank fraud, he
  concealed the information by failing to inform a judge or other person in
  authority of the felony.Â  The Acting United States Attorney charged respondent
  by Information and respondent pled guilty on June 18, 2008.Â  On October 17,
  2008, respondent was sentenced to twenty-four (24) months probation,
  performance of 100 hours of community service, and participation in the home confinement
  program with electronic monitoring for a period of four (4) months.Â  In
  addition, respondent was ordered to pay a fine of $3,000 and a special
  assessment of $100. 
Respondent self-reported
  this matter to ODC. Â Â Â 
Matter II
Respondent completed a
  series of closings on the same piece of property.Â  The last of the closings was
  for Mr. and Mrs. Doe who were the buyers of the property.Â  At the time of that
  closing, the mortgage on the property was to be paid from the closing proceeds,
  however, it was not satisfied of record and no release was executed and filed.Â 
  This failure complicated Mr. and Mrs. Doeâ€™s attempt to sell the property at a
  later date.Â  Respondent claims he did not personally receive notice of the
  issues regarding the property until after Mr. and Mrs. Doe obtained the
  satisfactions they required. 
Â Respondent admits he had
  previously represented a prior purchaser of the same property and that he
  failed to insure that the proper releases and/or satisfactions were filed by
  the lender after the July 7, 2005 closing.Â  Â 
LAW
Respondent
  admits he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional
  Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation);
    Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep a client reasonably informed about the status of a
    matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule
    8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(b)
    (lawyer shall not commit a criminal act that reflects adversely on the
  lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness or fitness as a lawyer in other respects);
  and Rule 8.4(d) (lawyer shall not engage
  in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation).Â  He
  further admits that
  his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to
  violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction
  regarding professional conduct of lawyers), Rule 7(a)(4) (it shall be ground
  for discipline for lawyer to be convicted of serious crime or crime of moral
  turpitude), and Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to
  engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring
  the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an
  unfitness to practice law).Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and impose a definite suspension of twelve months from the
  practice of law, retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim
  suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall
  file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with
  Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.[1]

DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ.,
  concur.


[1] Respondent shall not file a Petition for
  Reinstatement until he has completed all conditions of his sentence.Â  See Rule 33, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of J. Fitzgerald O’Connor, Jr., Respondent.


ORDER

On
  September 16, 2009, respondent was indicted on charges of conspiracy to commit
  mail fraud and money laundering in violation of 18 U.S.C. § 1001(a), 18 U.S.C.
  § 1341, 18 U.S.C. § 1503(a), 18 U.S.C. § 1503(b)(3), 18 U.S.C. § 1956(h), 18
  U.S.C. § 1957, 18 U.S.C. § 2, 18 U.S.C. § 981(a)(1)(C), 18 U.S.C. § 982(a)(1),
  and 28 U.S.C. § 2461(c).  As a result, the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC)
  has filed a petition asking this Court to place respondent on interim
  suspension pursuant to Rule 17, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, and requesting the Court
  appoint an attorney to protect respondent’s clients’ interests pursuant to Rule
  31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.  ODC states that respondent does not oppose issuance
  of the interim suspension.  
 
IT IS ORDERED that respondent’s
  license to practice law in this state is suspended until further order of the
  Court.
 
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that­­­­­­­
  Randolph Epting, Esquire, is hereby appointed to assume responsibility for
  respondent’s client files, trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating
  account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain.  Mr. Epting
  shall take action as required by Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, to protect the
  interests of respondent’s clients.  Mr. Epting may make disbursements from
  respondent’s trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any
  other law office account(s) respondent may maintain that are necessary to
  effectuate this appointment.
 
This Order, when served on any
  bank or other financial institution maintaining trust, escrow and/or operating
  accounts of respondent, shall serve as an injunction to prevent respondent from
  making withdrawals from the account(s) and shall further serve as notice to the
  bank or other financial institution that Randolph Epting, Esquire, has been
  duly appointed by this Court.
 
Finally, this Order, when
  served on any office of the United States Postal Service, shall serve as notice
  that Randolph Epting, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court and has
  the authority to receive respondent’s mail and the authority to direct that
  respondent’s mail be delivered to Mr. Epting’s office.
 
This appointment shall be for a
  period of no longer than nine months unless request is made to this Court for
  an extension.    
                              
IT IS SO ORDERED.



  
     
    s/Costa M. Pleicones       J.
      FOR THE COURT
  

Columbia, South Carolina
September 23, 2009
